title: trevor kavanagh boris public health bureaucrats
story: Boris Johnson is ready to reopen the pubs, restaurants and hairdressers that make ordinary le worth living by the end of this month or early July.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe plans a Save Our Summer campaign to salvage a crippled travel and leisure industry worth more than £billion — and the .million jobs that go with it.Months of self-isolation, closed shops and shuttered town centres may be nearly over.The PM is responding to dismay within his own ranks over the shambolic quarantine on air travellers, compulsory face masks and the absurd two-metre distancing rule.His focus sharpened last week when told about the likely jobs meltdown.“Christ!” he responded, and ordered a swt shake-up to the timetable for le to begin again.The PM is personally in tune with those who want rules relaxed.But he has been hemmed in by the same bumbling public-health bureaucrats who landed us with the worst Covid death toll in Europe and put the skids under the British economy.They include “Bonking Boffin” Professor Neil Ferguson, who triggered panic with alarmist predictions of , Covid corpses.But the key culprits are Public Health England, the quango whose sole responsibility is keeping us safe.Instead, they reacted like rabbits paralysed in the head-lights when the coronavirus burst out of Wuhan.Boris won’t put it like that when he addresses the nation with his plan of attack in the next week or two.But despite stern opposition from some scientic experts, he has decided the battle against the virus must be fought alongside, not after, the fight to save the health, wealth and prosperity of the nation.Track-and-trace plans will proceed at top speed, along with the search for a vaccine.The NHS will not drop its guard.But the PM is acutely aware of alarm among Tories over government floundering.“It goes from bad to worse,” said one loyalist minister. “We are looking confused. “The two-week quarantine rule is bonkers and so is the rule on face masks. “We may be popular in the polls, but governments are meant to lead public opinion, not follow.”Senior ministers, led by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, warn that each day lost before reopening Britain for business marks another swathe of jobs gone — some for ever.Mass unemployment, unseen since the Great Depression in the s, would devastate the Red Wall voters in the North and Midlands who put Boris into power.So the resumption of normal le has been brought forward by weeks.First to go will be the two-metre rule — already abandoned in reality on beaches, in parks and on Whitehall, where Black Lives Matter protesters hug each other.Strict social-distancing measures make bus and Tube travel virtually impossible. Boris wants distancing cut to one metre, giving the all-clear for pubs and restaurants to reopen and start rehiring the millions laid off since lockdown.Rishi Sunak is counting on this to trim Treasury job-support measures costing the economy a dizzying £billion.It will kickstart a new-normal summer, with open-air weddings, beer-garden service and marquees to protect punters from the rain.Summer holidays are back on track after being stymied for weeks.Airlines will bypass quarantine with air corridors to approved holiday destinations such as Italy, France, Greece and Turkey.These measures are not risk-free. Scientists point to a possible surge in Covid cases in the North.But equally reputable experts insist there is little chance of a second wave.The risk of the NHS failing to cope has now passed.Meanwhile, lockdown has brought its own death toll. Countless lives have certainly been lost from failure to diagnose and treat cancers and heart diseases.The price in lost schooling and crippled le chances will be paid for decades to come.Lting lockdown is a tough decision for any prime minister.But, as Boris knows better than most, to lead is to choose. It’s what he was elected for.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eastenders new tarzan speak was for the hard of thinking
story: THESE last three months, it’s seemed like only two places on Earth have avoided being trapped in lockdown.Sweden and EastEnders.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd I don’t know what state of paranoid despair the Scandinavians have been enduring but I would still take my chances pub crawling in downtown Malmo before I set foot in Walford, where the only acknowledgement of the coronavirus outbreak has been a practical one.To drag out the torture, it’s now only on twice a week. A delaying-the-inevitable tactic which meant, by the time Phil and Dennis’s tickets for the April  game between West Ham and Burnley arrived in mid May, the fixture was as dead as Dennis.A lucky escapeyou ask me.The day of reckoning, when it runs out of episodes, fast approaches, of course. For the duration of the outbreak, though, it’s been a biological miracle.Regulars have packed The Vic, mobbed the Bridge Street market and just stood around gawping and muttering, in their usual community-serving way, when Keegan’s sandwich van was trashed by the local drug dealers.The presence of a global pandemic hasn’t stopped EastEnders lecturing us about other medical issues, obviously.Since the boat party accident, in February, it’s been particularly concerned about Ben Mitchell’s deafness, which cut no ice with me for a couple of good reasons.Firstly, Ben Mitchell is a dreadful, immoral, six-headed little turd who it’s impossible to like, let alone love.Secondly, they’d forgotten he was partially deaf for most of the previous decade.There’s not an international crisis or continuity glitch in the universe that can stand in the way of EastEnders’ moral grandstanding, though, so they decided viewers should “see and hear” last week’s heist episode, with Barry Grant off Brookside, through the eyes and ears of Ben.A particularly gormless enterprise, this one, which went off like Norman Collier and Jimi Hendrix on the same bill at The Half Moon in Putney, and was all feedback and missing words.To ram home the message for the hard of thinking, the action was also accompanied by word cloud subtitles that appeared to have been written by Tarzan.“Keep mind on job.”“Cut power.”“Ben, this mistake.”“Daughter without father.”Compared with other EastEnders episodes, I enjoyed it a lot. I usually do when the show tries something a bit dferent and thought you could actually write the entire history of the show in half a dozen lines of this new Tarzan-speak.“Den hate Angie.” “Peter change head.” “Phil. Him shot.” “You not mother.” “Me am mother.” “Peter change head again.” “Get out pub.” It’d be timely as well. After  years and four months of almost constant shouting and stall-minding, EastEnders goes off air next week.Tantalisingly, The Sun’s very own Andy Halls reported, on Friday, that when it s the show will have dropped its old storylines. A dream scenario which allowed me to fantasise about EastEnders .. A happier, funnier show that’s only on twice a week, where the BBC doesn’t endlessly bask in its own right-on virtue and the majority of characters actually sound like Londoners, instead of stage-schooleditorials.But that’s not going to happen, is it So I’m just going to enjoy the silence. Tarzan like.TIPPING Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in the Midlands shares its name with a meeting between two sporting rivals ”Bill: “Birmingham.”Celebrity Mastermind, John Humphrys: “In an th century poem, what season of the year did Keats describe as ‘a season of mists and mellow fruitfulness’ ”Monty Panesar: “Oliver Twist.”Ben Shephard: “The Anglo-Dutch wars were fought primarily between England and which modern-day country ”Amy: “Denmark.”.THE Last Leg, Desiree Burch on the George Floyd fallout: “Follow black artists and thinkers on social media, people who have good resources, information, opinions and insights. Right now I have two shows you could watch — Desiree’s Coming Early and Tar Baby.”Or you could watch Too Hot To Handle, where Netflix films young people having sex while artist thinker Desiree offers her “insights and opinions”.But she’s clearly too modest to mention her role on that one.THIS week’s winner is Tory MP Andrew Bridgen and Harry Enfield’s Tim Nice But Dim. Sent in by RJ.FIRST job for the Beeb’s new Director General, Tim Davie  Find out how Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer ended up on primetime, Saturday night, BBC. Seriously, how  It’s a late-night ITV show, with no one to bleep out the swearing, but with BBC levels of over-manning.The star, obviously, was Peter Crouch, who’s actually funnier than  per cent of TV comedians and more likable than all of them, but not yet ready to front his own show. So they added Maya Jama, who looked sensational in her Status Quo Blue For You-era denims, the compulsory Horne Section and Chris Ramsey, who was hiding behind a fence at the start. And should’ve stayed there. All deserve our sympathy. SOS was meant to be a Euro  spin-off and when the tournament vanished so did the show’s point. Camera angles also seem to have gone to hell, but that’s maybe an act of socially distanced mercy given what’s happening front and centre.Saturday’s content included: A teabag- flipping contest between Mo Farah and Ellie Simmonds, parachuting with Jermaine Jenas, which was straight off the Alan Partridge script and foul-mouthed football “bantz” from Rio Ferdinand, who said his career was ended by Peter Crouch, so may have been playing keepy-uppy to the Match Of The Day theme tune as some sort of twisted payback.The really alarming thing, though, is the series lasts eight weeks.Save Our Summer  At this rate, there’ll be a dark cloud hanging over autumn as well.For the record, it was the BBC News.SPRINGWATCH’s Steve Backshall wearing a “No planet B” T-shirt like he’s a -year-old student, rather than a -year-old BBC presenter who won’t shut up about his three kids. Bafta giving nominations to The Greatest Dancer and The Ranganation but not a Best Drama nod to Line Of Duty.This Morning’s Phillip Schofield losing his very short temper with John Torode over yoghurt dressing. Anyone who says “chowing down” instead of eating. And the clearly smitten GMB host Susanna Reid making an involuntary groping gesturewith her left hand, just after she says the name Keir Starmer. Easy tiger.PETER Crouch: “It wasn’t all about improving, it was also about getting better.”Ian Wright: “The one thing about Gerrard was his professionalism and the fact he was so versatile.”Paul Merson: “It was definitely half an open goal.”                                 SKY Documentaries’ McMillion, the best show on TV.Ralph’s wedding on The A Word. ITV’s th birthday tribute to the great Bradley Walsh.The GMB spat between Piers Morgan and Donald Trump’s lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, which had everything except the obvious reprimand: “Rudy. Stop your messin’ around.”And Channel ’s Murder In The Outback, where disgraced Australian lawyer Andrew Fraser proves, beyond much forensic doubt, Bradley Murdoch did indeed kill Peter Falconio.The only slight glitch being, he’s trying to prove the exact opposite.Watch it, Channel , tonight and tomorrow, pm. The self-delusion becomes hypnotic. A Gillian Burke on Springwatch B Connell Waldron on Normal People C Comedian Tom Allen on nearly everything MOST surprising thing about Britain’s Best Parent  Anita Rani isn’t the most annoying person on this Channel  show.In fact, she’s not even close to a medal position thanks to the other five – two couples and a single mum – who must champion their own style of parenting, whether  it’s “pushy” or “vegan” or mollycoddling or just sort of lying around in bed all day treating their offspring as the hired help.Like the rest of us, Channel  silently understands, of course, listening to strangers talk about their small children is no more engaging or enlightening than listening to a ­scientologist talk about L. Ron Hubbard, so they’ve included a few eccentrics to liven  up the process.On the one hand there’s martial arts enthusiast Robin, who explains: “Our parenting style is influenced by eastern philosophy. Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism,” ventriloquism, egotism, Roxette’s fourth album Tourism.On the other there’s gender fluid feminist nut Joana, who is attempting to bring up five-year-old son Willow as “a free spirit”, by banning the word “boy”, refusing to buy him “militaristic toys” and plastering her house in idiotic Socialist Worker propaganda.Hopefully, little Willow will be a stalwart of his local golf club and TA unit  in about  years’ time.But that’s no real saving grace for the show, nor a reason to watch any part of Britain’s Best Parent, apart from the final vote where, every week, the studio audience has to choose between those “free spirits” who let the kids rule the roost and those couples, like David and Nicky, who run their house more like an SAS boot camp.And every week, I’m happy to report, they vote for the boot camp.All hope for Britain may not be lost.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: black lives matter statues sadiq khan
story: Protest groups have drawn up a list of statues they want torn down after Edward Colstons was tossed into the harbour in Bristol by Black Lives Matter protesters at the weekend, and last night a monument to Robert Milligan was removed from Londons Docklands.The news comes after London Mayor Sadiq Khan demanded statues and plaques be removed and street names in London changedthey commemorate slave owners.Mr Khan told Sky News: Weve got to realise that our public realm statues, squares, street names dont accurately reflect our values, or London, in .But he added: I dont condone at all any attacks on our police, any disorder or criminal damages.Meanwhile, it has been announced  Labour councils across England and Wales will begin reviewing monuments and statues in their towns and cities.It means dozens more monuments could be removed.A statement posted on Twitter said: LGA Labour have consulted with all Labour council leaders, and there is overwhelming agreement from all Labour councils that they will listen to and work with their local communities to review the appropriateness of local monuments and statues on public land and council property.And in Scotland, Adam McVey, leader of Edinburgh city council, told BBC Radio Scotland he would feel “absolutely no sense of loss”the statue of Henry Dundas, st Viscount Melville responsible for delaying the abolition of the slave trade by  years, was removed from the ft Melville Monument.Yesterday  a statue of Robert Milligan - thought to have owned some  slaves - was removed from the West India Quay in east London following a petition from a Labour MP.Milligan was the driving force behind the building of the West India Docks in London.He also traded slaves in Jamaica.Reports say the statues removal was met with cheers and applause from onlookers.Milligans statue had stood outside the Museum of the Docklands near the West India Quay he helped create near Canary Wharf.London Mayor Sadiq Khan added the Commission for Diversity in the Public Realm would work to introduce statues and memorials which better reflect London including the inclusion of more black, disabled and LGBTQ+ people.Some of statues that could be part of a cull are slave traders and owners William Beckford, John Cass and Thomas Guy.Former Lord Mayor of London William Beckford, who has a statue inside Londons Guildhall, is believed to have owned around , slaves in plantations in Jamaica.Sir John Cass was a philanthropist and a slaver, who was a member of the Royal African Companys Court of Assistance for three years in the s.The foundation set up in memory of him provides support to schools and universities in London - including the Cass Business school.Thomas Guy, who one Kings College Londons campuses is named after, made his fortune off of investing in the slave trade.Yesterday, people were spotted trying to fish the statue of Colston out of the Bristol harbour as conflict emerged over how the protesters have behaved and whether statues should be removed.A website called Topple the Racists has been set up mapping out all the statues across Britain they demand should be taken down.Senior police chief Andy Bennet, who led the Avon and Somerset police operation in Bristol during the protests, said having officers guard the statue would have led to further violence and vandalism in the city.He said Bristol should be proud of the way the city handled the protests.He told the Bristol Post: “No one got hurt and we had no arrests in the whole protest. That is , passionate people — Bristol should be proud of itself.”William Beckford - plantation owner Former Lord Mayor of London William Beckford, who has a statue inside Londons Guildhall, is believed to have owned around , slaves in plantations in Jamaica.Sir John Cass - member of the Royal African CompanySir John Cass was a philanthropist and a slaver, who was a member of the Royal African Companys Court of Assistance for three years in the s.The foundation set up in memory of him provides support to schools and universities in London - including the Cass Business school.Thomas Guy - made money off the slave tradeThomas Guy, who one Kings College Londons campuses is named after, made his fortune off of investing in the slave trade.Mr Khan said the recommendations from the new commission would probably be that some statues would have to be pulled down.He claried: I suspect the commission may come back and say its not appropriate to be memorialising, to be celebrating these people.Its a discussion we should have and its really important to bring in erse voices, we can imagine - there are statues of people who were involved in the Royal African Company in London.There are statues of plantation owners and their contribution is solely the money they made through plantations.But Mr Khan said not all statues would be included in the review - such as that of famed former Prime Minister Winston Churchill, whose memorial was defaced by protester who wrote he was a racist over the weekend.The London Mayor said people needed to learn about famous figures, such as Churchill, Gandhi and Malcolm X, warts and all and that nobody was perfect.Following the tearing down of the statue of Edward Colston, there are fears the statue of Cecil Rhodes at Oxford University could also be taken down as protesters plan to stage a demonstration at pm.The Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group has called for the image of the mining magnate and empire builder to be removed from Oriel College, arguing the university has failed to address its institutional racism.His comments come after Boris Johnson slammed protesters for taking the law into their own hands and pulling down the statue of Costol in Bristol over the weekend.The PM said:desecrate public monuments, we have a democracy in this country.If you want to change the urban landscape, you can stand for election or vote for someone who will.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann new image campervan
story: A Spanish investigator has spent days scouring old satellite imagery after the -year-old serial child sex beast was identied last week.And German police and Scotland Yard have now been sent a picture which could show the roof of the VW Westfalia T van parked near his former Praia da Luz home.The image could prove crucial because it suggests the distinctive van was taken back to open land Christian B was familiar with after living close-by for six years.But it raises questions over why Christian B ed to the farmhouse just days after Madeleine vanished when he was living in the campervan, not the run-down home.Imagery shows the white roof of a van of similar dimensions to the VW parked beside a hedge yards from a ramshackle single-storey former farmhouse plot.He lived there with a German lover from  to , when he did a runner and left the building strewn with debris including wigs and smashed computer gear.But the picture shows the van appears to have been driven back to the plot - which is surrounded by scrubland littered with deep, abandoned well shafts.One of the old stone wells is visible a few feet from the van.The image was captured days after three-year-old Madeleine went missing at the very start of the massive police search.A Portuguese investigating source said last night: “If that is the van in that spot - so soon after the abduction - the image could be extremely signicant.“He would have known that area well having lived there for six years but he had left the farmhouse months earlier.“So why did he go back at a time when everyone was looking for missing Madeleine ”Christian B, now , split with his German partner after tempestuous rows at the ramshackle farmhouse.In June , Scotland Yard detectives - backed by a team of cadaver dogs and ground penetrating radar - excavated land  yards from the building but unearthed no clues.But their focus was on ground closer to the main road and it is not clearthey checked the many wells dotted around the landscape.The beauty spot is also well known to Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry, who regularly jogged around Black Rock after launching the hunt for their daughter in Praia da Luz in May .Cops are now preparing to dig up land around two Portuguese lairs where he lived.Locals - who described Christian B as a “quiet, angry weirdo” - say he would have known the area well and believe vital evidence may have been missed.Spanish investigator Heriberto Janosch Gonzálezfound discovered the picture during a trawl of satellite records last week.He said: “For the last five days I was looking for evidence concerning the houses and vehicles belonging to Madeleine McCanns crime new suspect Christian B, following Scotland Yard Operation Grange and German Bundeskriminalmatappeals.“I found a NASA satellite photograph taken days after the abduction of Madeleine.“It shows one of the houses where he lived, and an image totally congruent with the dimensions and colour of the VW Westfalia van that the suspect were using at that time.“I have passed this information to Operation Grange and German Bundeskriminalmatyesterday .“If he is involved in Madeleine McCann abduction, as the police appeals suggested, maybe he carried her to that place, and some evidence or her remains were hidden in that location.“Will the police search that house and the field around, including the wells ”Police in Germany fear the drter, who stole from hotels in Praia da Luz, may have snatched Madeleine after first entering the holiday home to raid it.Among the growing body of facts linking him to Madeleines disappearance is he was revealed to be living in a campervan in the area around the time the youngster vanished on May , .As well as the campervan, the drug dealer and burglar also been linked to a  Jaguar XJR with a German number plate seen in Praia da Luz and surrounding areas in  and .On May ,  - the day after Madeleine vanished - he got the Jaguar re-registered in Germany under someone s name although it is believed the vehicle remained in Portugal.German police believe one of the two vehicles were used in the disappearance of Madeleine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sky news apologises prince andrew shown madeleine mccann suspect clip
story: During last nights broadcast, TV host Dermot Murnaghan introduced the bulletins top story about the investigation into Madeleines disappearance.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Madeleine McCannHe told viewers: We have actual evidence Madeleine McCann is dead. German prosecutors reveal more on their investigation into the suspect, Christian B.In the unfortunate mix-up, Sky News then aired a video of Prince Andrew in conservation with another man who had his back to the camera.Sky News later issued an apology for the blunder.Murnaghan, who looked rather startled, said: Now in the headlines at the start of this hour, we featured headlines in the wrong order.We included a picture of Prince Andrew in the headline about the investigation into Christian B, the German suspect in the Madeleine McCann.We apologise for this mistake.It comes as a German prosecutor yesterday said there is some evidence that Madeleine was killed by the new suspect in the case but not enough to bring him to trial.Hans Christian Wolters, the Braunschweig state prosecutor, said police needed more information about where Christian B had lived so police could search for Madeleines body.Mr Wolters told Sky News: The hard evidence we dont have, we dont have the crucial evidence of Madeleine McCanns body.We expect that she is dead, but we dont have enough evidence that we can get a warrant for our suspect in Germany for the murder of Madeleine McCann.At the moment, we also dont have enough proof for a trial at court, but we have some evidence that the suspect has done the deed.Thats why we need more information from people, especially places he has lived, so we can target these places especially and search there for Madeleine.Christian B is known to have lived on the Algarve coast and his Portuguese mobile phone received a half-hour phone call in Praia da Luz around an hour before Madeleine, then three, went missing on May  .Madeleine vanished shortly before her fourth birthday, while her parents were eating dinner with friends at a nearby tapas restaurant, and would have turned  last month. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: owl tree photographer spot it
story: The elusive avian was almost perfectly camouflaged in a tree in the famous Masai Mara game reserve in Kenya.Ingo Gerlach, , from Betzdorf, Germany, took the images while visiting the park.The graphic designer and photographer captured a milk eagle owl hidden in a treeBut admits the image was a fluke as he had no idea there was an owl in the shot.He added: It took me about  minutes to spot the fact theres an owl up the tree.My driver spotted it. It was almost impossible for me to discover the eagle owl.Africa is home to more than  species of owl and new species are being discovered.The milk eagle owl is the largest in Africa, measuring up to  inches in totaland is a resident primarily of dry, wooded savanna. The Masai Mara is one of the most famous and important wildle conservation and wilderness areas in Africa.More than  species of birds have been identied in the park, many of which are migrants.It is also home to the so-called big five animals of Africa – lion, leopard, cheetah, elephant and buffalo.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clothes charity shops reopen monday
story: Non-essential retail will begin to open back up from next week as the Government tries to get Britains businesses up and running after months of shut down.Brits will be able to start shopping again and donating their clothes to charity stores after months of lockdown sort-outs.The move is part of the Governments efforts to kickstart Britains economy after most shops and businesses have been forced to keep their doors closed since March .Alok Sharma said this evening: Now thanks to the efforts of the British people we have succeeded in reducing the number of infections and getting the R rateunder control. That is why we can carefully begin to open parts of economy in a phased and careful manner.I can confirm today that retail outlets which have been required to close will be able to open their doors again from Monday June , so long as they comply with the Covid secure guidelines This is the latest step in the careful restarting of our economy and will enable high streets up and down the country to spring back to le.The Government has said the R rate is between . and . but fears have grown it could have tipped over  in some areas of the UK. If it goes past  the virus could start to spread again with warp speed and cause a dreaded second peak in Britain.Businesses will need to complete a COVID- risk assessment before opening and will need to display a notice in their windows declaring they have put steps in place to stop the spread of the virus.Customers will have to follow strict social distancing rules and shops will have to limit the number of people allowed in - forcing people to wait in supermarket style queues.Hand sanitiser stations for staff and customers will need to be installed in stores and ed items will need to be quarantined for  hours in case they carry germs which could spread for coronavirus.The Government is under increasing pressure to relax the  metre social distancing rule so shops can recover quicker by allowing more people into their shops.Mr Sharma said this evening they were keeping the  metre rule but they were taking a cautious view on this.The Business Secretary said: I completely understand why for economical reasons businesses will want to have a look at this  metre rule, as I said with all of these matters, we keep this under review.This is about what is safe and we will only make changes when it is safe to do so.Shoppers could also be banned from trying on clothes or testing make-up and other products to limit the spread of germs. Some shops have taken an innovative approach to social distancing measures - Aldi created a traffic-light system so customers know when it is safe to enter a store.Outdoor markets and car showrooms were allowed to open earlier this month.The hospitality sector is gearing up for pubs and restaurants to reopen in July, with hopes outdoor beer gardens could open as soon as June .Mr Sharma confirmed the Government was working to the timetable laid out by the Prime Minister last month, and the opening date for the hospitality sector would not be until July.He said: As soon as we can, we will publish further guidance for restaurants, pubs and bars as well as hairdresser, barbers, nail bars and related services.There has been a lot of speculation about when they might be able to reopen. I understand why we are all so keen, I share that.We continue to follow the roadmap which sets out our ambition to reopen these sectors from  July at the earliest. To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: north korea severs contact south phones kim jong un hiding
story: The move follows Kim Jong-uns emergence from hiding after weeks out of the public eye and widespread speculation about his health. A report on the state-run Korean Central News Agencysaid that the North would shut off all communication from midday today. In the absence of formal diplomatic relations or embassies, the two countries typically communicate via a jointly-run body called the Inter-Korean Liaison Office. The office maintains a number of lines of communication, including hotlines between senior figures within the countries militaries as well as their presidential offices. The North has released a series of statements over the last week threatening to close the officethe South did not stop defectors sending anti-regime material back over the border. Defectors from North Korea are known to use a number of methods, including pamphlets dropped from small air balloons, to get information back into the country. The move is likely also part of diplomatic manoeuvring related to severe international sanctions currently in place on the North, the Times reported. The sanctions are thought to be having a devastating impact on North Koreas economy and population. Despite the decision only officially coming into force today, a spokesperson for the South Korean ministry of defence said routine daily calls made through the liaison office yesterday went unanswered. Daniel Wertz, Programme Manager at the National Committee on North Korea, tweeted that severing communications was a well-worn play for the North, but a dangerous one amid the coronavirus crisis. The spat comes after Kim Jong-un disappeared from view for almost three weeks in April, prompting speculation about his health as well as reports of his death. He reemerged at the beginning of May, and this week was seen smiling at a meeting of senior officials from the ruling Workers Party.The KNCA report stated that Kim and other senior figures in Pyongyang had decided that “the work towards the South should thoroughly turn into one against an enemy”.“[The North Korean people have] been angered by the treacherous and cunning behaviour of the South Korean authorities, with whom we will have lots of accounts to settle, it said. “We have reached a conclusion that there is no need to sit face to face with the South Korean authorities and there is no issue to discuss with them, as they have only aroused our dismay.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew never cooperate jeffrey epstein
story: Sources have reportedly claimed Prince Andrew will not get behind the investigation as he believes US attorney Geoffrey Berman wants to make an example of him.Insiders said Prince Andrew would have already fully cooperatednot for the aggressive actions of the US attorney in pursuing him.The Duke of Yorks team reportedly fear the lawyer wants to turn him into a scapegoat for the failures of the case - and sources said its now virtually impossible for him to cooperate.It comes amid a back and forth between Andrews team and Mr Berman as the Royal insisted he had offered to assist in the investigation three times. Mr Berman however issued a statement which accused the Prince of ly portraying himself to the public as eager and willing to co-operate. The US Department of Justice has filed a mutual legal assistance request to the Home Office - which formally asks for help to question the Royal.Andrew is facing ongoing scrutiny over his links to convicted sex offender Epstein, who was at the centre of a web of sex trafficking and abuse before killing himself in jail last August.The Duke has always denied any improper behaviour over his relationship with Epstein, and strongly denies allegations he slept with sex slave Virginia Roberts when she was .Sources have claimed Andrew may never cooperate with the probe while Mr Berman is in charge, reports the " href"https:www.telegraph news    epstein-prosecutor-has-made-impossible-prince-andrew-co-operate " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener". Insiders insist that Andrew should remain a witness rather than a target in the federal investigation into Epstein.The source said: The Duke would have cooperated fully with Berman had he not chosen to make an example of him.What we saw yesterday was a trebling down by Berman on this consistent modus operandi of throwing away the rule book and commenting on what are supposed to be completely confidential discussions surrounding the co-operation of a witness.The source added: Why does he get to tear the rule book up  Who does he think he is  There is no way that statement was designed to encourage the Duke to co-operate. It was a sarcastic, knee-jerk response to a very reasonable and factually accurate statement about the assistance the Duke has offered so far. In fact, all it does is confirm what we have been dealing with here all along.Royal insiders accused Mr Berman of seeking publicity and attempting to use Andrew as a scapegoat for the failures of the case.Andrew is claimed to have been first contacted by authorities in January, despite Epstein being investigated for  years. Mr Berman previously claimed the Duke has offered zero cooperation back in January, and then said the Royal had completely shut the door on the probe in March.The source said: Every time Berman has opened his mouth, he has undermined his own case.Lawyers for the Duke of York, , have insisted he has offered to give a witness statement to investigators probing Epstein.Mr Berman, the US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, has accused Andrew of repeatedly refusing to cooperate - and alleges the Dukes team unequivocally told his office in March he would not be quizzed.Lawyer Gloria Allred, who represents some of Epsteins victims, told BBCs Newsnight: Justice delayed is justice denied and he needs to stop playing a cat and mouse game with the United States Department of Justice.He needs to stop delaying and trying to evade answering questions and he should not be setting any conditions,in fact thats what hes doing.It comes as William Barr, the US Attorney General, said the Duke of York will not be extradited to the US for questioning over his links into Epstein.Andrews legal firm also hit out at earlier claims from Mr Berman that there has been a wall of silence from the Duke.Blackfords LLP acting for the royal said: The Duke of York has on at least three occasions this year offered his assistance as a witness to the DOJ. Unfortunately, the DOJ has reacted to the first two offers by breaching their own confidentiality rules and claiming that the Duke has offered zero cooperation.In doing so, they are perhaps seeking publicity rather than accepting the assistance proffered.The Sun Online has contacted Andrews lawyers for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. dficult for me to predict what is going to happen in the coming weeks and what the scientic advice is going to be.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told MPs he hopes all kids will get back to title: labour leader keir starmer takes a knee george floyd
story: He was pictured alongside his deputy Angela Rayner, and said on Twitter: We kneel with all those opposing anti-Black racism #BlackLivesMatter”.The phrase take a knee is a protest against the unfair treatment of Black Americans, coming from an American football play.The poignant stance has been adopted by the Black Lives Matter movement and has swept the world in recent protests.Sir Keir shared a picture ‘taking a knee’ this afternoon as demonstrators met in Parliament Square to mark George Floyd’s funeral.Despite coronavirus fears, tens of thousands have protested in the wake of Floyd’s death in Minneapolis police custody, after officer Derek Chauvin pressed his knee into the handcuffed African-American’s neck for nearly nine minutes despite Floyd’s cries of “I can’t breathe”.Parliament came to a halt at am for a minutes silence in memory of Floyd, with Sir Keir addressing his murder afterwards.The Labour leader said: “He must not become just another name. His death must be a catalyst for change.”The official Downing Street spokesperson revealed that the prime minister and his cabinet did not take part in the minute’s silence.Boris Johnson reportedly told ministers there is “so much more to do in eradicating prejudice and creating opportunity”.The spokesperson said: “The PM began Cabinet by discussing the anger and the grief that is not just felt in the US but around the world including the UK following the death of George Floyd.”“He said those who lead and govern simply cannot ignore the depth of emotion that has been triggered.”“The PM said there was an undeniable feeling of injustice and that people from black and minority ethnic groups do face discrimination in education, in employment and in the application of criminal law.“The PM said we’re a much, much less racist society than we were but we must also frankly acknowledge that there’s so much more to do in eradicating prejudice and creating opportunity.”Last night, Boris Johnson sent a message to the UK, saying the Black Lives Matter protesters cannot be ignored but rioters must face the full force of the law.In a Twitter video message last night, he acknowledged the concerns of anti-racist protesters are founded on a cold reality.However, he warned there would be consequences to those who damage property or harm the police.Mr Johnson added he would not support those who break social distancing rules.The Met Police said they arrested  people over the weekend and added dozens of officers suffered injuries.

It just doesn’t bear thinking about.“What he said at that dinner suggests he planned the whole thing very carefully and that he might even have stolen Madeleine to order.“But we also can’t help feeling guilty thinking we should have pulled together all the clues years ago and gone to the police.”The friend, a man in his s from North Yorkshire who has lived in Lagos for more than ten years, met Christian B when he worked at the expat bar, called The Tavern.He said: “" rel"noreferrer noopener"Christian had a camper van but wasn’t a hippy as has been said.“He wasn’t a bad-looking bloke and was always well groomed.“He was quite brash and loud and was also a bit of a charmer and I could see why women might be attracted to him.“But I never liked him because I’m a close friend of both of the British girls he dated and they both told me he beat them up.“They’ve both been beside themselves for days since the police appeals and don’t know what to do.“Their first priority is to help police because they know a lot of things that probably join up a lot of the dots in the investigation.”The friend said the women are desperate to ensure Christian B, currently in jail after the rape of a -year-old woman in Praia da Luz in , remains locked up.He added: “Their main concern is making sure he’s convicted and stays in prison because they know what kind of person he is.“They’re terried he might get out one day and come for them.”One of the women is a mum of two from Berkshire. She lived in Praia da Luz when she dated convicted paedophile Christian B in the early s.She is understood to have been questioned previously by detectives at her current home in Lagos but the nature of her evidence has not come to light until now.She has now spoken again to police re-focusing inquiries on -year-old Christian B, who is serving his prison sentence in Germany. The ex-girlfriend is not a suspect but agreed to co-operate by giving a statement.She is a friend of the other British woman, also in a relationship with Christian B in the noughties.There is no suggestion either of the women had any clue about any involvement he might have had in the abduction of the British toddler.The ex-husband of one of the women, a businessman who still lives in Lagos, was also spoken to by Interpol last year as police pieced together Christian Bs history.He has refused to say what police asked or how he knew Christian B.The husband said: “We’ve decided not to talk. The police have been in touch and we’ve spoken to them. I spoke to Interpol last year.“I’m speaking on behalf of my ex too. We don’t want to be involved.”The women’s testimony was disclosed as German police announced they have evidence suggesting Madeleine was murdered. They are also investigating Christian B over the unsolved murder of nine-year-old Peggy Knobloch, whose childhood snaps display a resemblance to Madeleine.She vanished on her way home from school in Thueringen, Baia, in May . Fteen years later parts of her skeleton were found in a forest  miles away.Christian B was freed from a two-year sentence for a child sex attack months before Peggy was abducted.Peggy’s mum Susanne said: “The Madeleine case takes me back to this time, everything comes up again.”In  a man with learning dficulties who lived near Peggy’s home was jailed for le after confessing to her murder.He later retracted his confession and was freed after ten years when his conviction was overturned.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family woes the queen let go of reigns
story: Unencumbered by a relentless schedule of pressing the flesh around the country, she’s having the first extended break of her admirably dutul le.A rare sighting of her on horseback shows her deep in thought, perhaps reflecting, as we all do in moments of quiet contemplation, on the well- being of her loved ones. In her case, it’s not pretty.Where to start  How about son number two who, thanks to his friendship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein is now embroiled in an ugly, cross-Atlantic ding dong with an American legal system that kowtows to no one.Clearly, Andrew hoped his royal status might ensure discretion. But the US Department of Justice has other ideas and has now publicly accused him of lying when he says he has offered to co-operate with their inquiries into Epstein’s questionable activities.It’s uncertain whether The Queen and Prince Philip have Netflix in their lockdown lair at Windsor Castle, butthey have watched the documentary Jeffrey Epstein: Filthy Rich — in which their reportedly favourite son is mentioned many times — they will have spat out their popcorn.Aside from the well- documented claim by Virginia Roberts that she was trafficked to London at the age of  to have sex with Prince Andrew , one of the most damning accusations is the alleged sighting of him at Epstein’s private island where airport staff now say that the billionaire, who allegedly killed himself last year, frequently arrived with “underage girls”.Ordinary people staying schtum at the time for fear of losing their jobs is one thing but the silence of the many powerful men who enjoyed Epstein’s hospitality is quite another.Prince Andrew is undoubtedly one of them and, at the very least, he owes it to Epstein’s survivors to sit down with the US Department of Justice and reveal what he does, or doesn’t, know.And asthat’s not enough to give his mother sleepless nights, he and his ex-we Sarah Ferguson are also being sued for a £.million unpaid debt on a Swiss ski chalet.Meanwhile, son number oneis happy enough in his second marriage, but reportedly harbouring a deep sadness that one of his sons has chosen to leg it to the US, along with the baby grandson he can no longer hug.On top of that, he faces forking out millions to help Harry and Meghan pay for personal protection because not only have they chosen to settle down in paparazzi central, but in a country where the gun culture means any nutter can wander into a store and arm up as easily as buying a microwave.Son number threehas just announced that his children won’t use royal titles and will work for a living.But one wonders whether, given the pressure to streamline the monarchy, they jumped before they were pushed.Daughter Anne is a reliable stalwart, but grandson Peter recently announced his marriage to we Autumn is over, and as for grandsons William and Harry, it’s fair to say that the reported fall-out of those two young brothers who walked so stoically behind their mother’s coffin must be causing The Queen great sadness.So, with all that going on with her nearest and dearest, how will she feel when lockdown finally lts and she’s expected to put on a brave face to the world again Will she think, “I’ve had enough” and, as was rumoured prior to the pandemic, abdicate on her th birthday next year Doubtful, given that she pledged she would be of service “my whole le” and that, traditionally, British monarchs occupy the throne until death.But, given her family ructions, who could blame hershe did decide to call it a day If he had bodyguards with him on his ious visits to Epstein, then perhaps they could enlighten the US authorities on Andrew’s movements at the time Andhe didn’t, then why the hell does he need them now Asthe new, -day quarantine rule wasn’t daft enough, it’s emerged that police have been told to take “no immediate action”a passenger gives a  address on arrival in the UK.Right. So the only travellers affected by this ludicrous policy will be the law-abiding and public figures who risk being spotted on holiday then named and shamedthey don’t self-isolate upon .Everyone  can just give their details as Mickey Mouse of Taking The Mickey Street, and go about their le with impunity.Meanwhile, the airline industry is teetering on the verge of bankruptcy because it sends out the message that Britain is closed.Well. Done. Everyone.Prince Albert of Monaco has a problem – his subjects are getting too old.According to the BBC documentary Inside Monaco, it’s the most elderly country on Earth.So the principality has launched an “influencer” award aimed at attracting a younger “YouTube” generation who,the footage of their garish supercars is anything to go by, have money but zero taste.The awards are the brainchild of the prince’s friend . . .  . . .  Princess Camilla of Bourbon Two Sicilies, Duchess of Castro If Little Britain ever doesto our screens, she’s a shoo-in.Dancing On Ice is reportedly considering filming the show with two-metre social-distancing measures in place.If the rumours of their big fallout are true, last series contestant Caprice and her dance partner Hamish Gaman would have had no trouble with implementing it.Pixar’s animated movie Coco has been voted the most tear-jerking film of all time, with Marley  Me in second place and Schindler’s List in third.It was the result of a Twitter survey by US film critic Kevin Lee, who asked followers to tell him “the hardest you’ve ever cried in a movie TV show”.I haven’t seen Coco, but my weepiest, cinematic experience didn’t make the top ten.It’s Mask – starring Cher and Eric Stolz – a film that rendered me so inconsolable that the man in front of me askedI could “shut the hell up”.And Goodbye Mr Chips wasn’t far behind either – but at least I was home on the sofa for that one.Other than Leonardo DiCaprio browsing for a new girlfriend, who actually shops at underwear store Victoria’s Secret any more Not many Brits, it seems – its  UK stores have just gone in to administration.Back in the day, VS underwear was tasteful and good quality, but somewhere along the way it lost sight of its core customer.The owners clearly forgot that, while men lusted after the scantily-clad “Angels” such as Alessandra Ambrosio at its catwalk shows , it’s primarily women who buy lingerie.And the majority want “tastefully boudoir” not “garishly bordello”.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: zoo safari open next monday
story: The PM decided to lt restrictions on outdoor attractions to offer families more options to entertain their kids after  weeks in lockdown.He will announce them as part of the latest easing of the coronavirus lockdown coming into effect on June .It is a win for The Sun’s campaign to reopen zoos and comes after we pressured the Government to give £million to help zoos and aquariums care for animals during the pandemic.Mr Johnson will say at the Downing Street press conference tomorrow that they can reopen next week as long as they can uphold social distancing rules following mounting pressure over the exponential threat posed by the pandemic.He will also announce the easing of restrictions on outdoor attractions where people remain in their cars, such as safari parks and drive-in cinemas, because the risk of spreading the disease is lower outside.It comes as the full list of shops allowed to reopen next week has also been revealed.A Downing Street official said last night: People are continuing to make huge sacrices to reduce the spread of coronavirus and avoid a second spike, but we know it is tough and where we can safely open up more attractions, and it is supported by the science, we will do so.This is by necessity a careful process, but we hope the reopening of safari parks and zoos will help provide families with more options to spend time outdoors while supporting the industry caring for these incredible animals.The announcement will come after London Zoo and other institutions across the nation warned they may face permanent closurethey were not allowed to reopen.The PMs father, Stanley Johnson, had joined calls for zoos to reopen as soon as possible after they were ordered to close when the lockdown was imposed on March .Though the easing will be a relief, zoos will be told that they must not reopen indoor exhibitions, such as reptile houses, and must ensure amenities including cafes are take-away only.The relaxation comes as the Government faces criticism over its handling of schools after Education Secretary Gavin Williamson conceded English primaries will not be able to welcome back all pupils before the summer holidays as planned.Children in nursery, Reception, Year  and Year  in England began ing to primary school last week but some schools have said they do not have the space to admit all pupils while following Government advice to limit class sizes to .Mr Williamsons concession will mean many primary school children will notto classes until September, along with most students in secondary school.Andrew Hall, spokesperson for Biaza - British and Irish Association for Zoos and Aquariums, said: Biaza is obviously delighted that zoos and safari parks have been given the flexibility to reopen.But as a sector, we are not out of the woods. Aquariums are still closed, and zoos and safari parks have taken a real hit. For some zoos, particularly those reliant on tourism, reopening isnt going to be financially viable for them.Its helpful today but its not the full answer to the challenges we face. title: ibiza beaches poo contamination
story: Environmental officials launched an investigation on the famous Balearic party island, off the east coast of Spain, after taking  samples from beaches last year.The Observatory of Sustainability in Ibiza commemorated World Ocean Day yesterday by sharing the test results.Illegal quantities of faeces were found on six beaches in Ibiza - a problem both for beachgoers and animals living by the coast or in the sea - which led to the ban of bathing.A press release released by the Observatory said: Six [beaches] were shown to have quantities of faecal contamination superior to those legally permitted, which led to the prohibition of bathing.The beaches in question were Talamanca, Bahia de Sant Antoni, Escollera de Sant Antoni, Es Pouet, Port de Sant Miquel and Platges de Comte.Data from the Ibiza water board said: In  all the samples analysed were excellent and ten years later solo  samples achieved this classication.The Observatory added: The decrease in the quality of the water in Ibiza highlights the lack of current infrastructure.They are incapable of facing up to the increase of visitors in the high season.The group said the only way to improve this situation and protect the marine le on the coast is to improve the sanitation and depuration and carry out a strict vigilance through quality controls.According to local media, the issue of untreated toilet waste being pumped into the sea is an ongoing problem in many seaside resorts in Spain.A recent report by the European Agency for the Environment found that , per cent of the beaches tested were under the minimum levels of contamination.Those who were reported to have unacceptable water quality were found to contain levels of Escherichia Coliand Intestinal enterococcus in levels which could be harmful to human health.

title: primary school target scrapped
story: The admission came as ministers confirmed they have scrapped a pledge to get all primary kids back in for a month before summer.Furious MPs and campaigners said the reopening of pubs and theme parks are being prioritised over children’s le chances.They called for a “national ­crusade” to create “Nightingale schools” in village halls and churches to get kids learning again.A government source said they expect schools to reopen for “more pupils” by September but are ­taking a “cautious approach”.Education Secretary Gavin ­Williamson told MPs he hopes all kids willto class in September, but fell short of promising to.He said: “While we are not able to welcome all primary children back for a full month before the summer, we continue to work with the sector on the next steps.“We would like to see schools who have the capacity to bring back more children in those smaller class sizes, to do sothey are able to do before the summer holidays. title: banning china huawei 5g world less safe
story: The ex-head of cyber security at the governments listening post GCHQ, said banging China out would split the internet in two and make attacks between each side more likely.China relies on western tech – its army uses Microsoft Windows and the telecoms firm Huawei uses hi-tech US chips to make its G kit, he said.The tactic of banging China out, and encouraging allies to do the same pushes us down a strategic path that, in the end, makes the globe less secure, he warned.It is far more sensible to think of a future with them entangled and entwined with US and Chinese technology.A global US crackdown on companies selling chips to Huawei will bolster Beijing’s homegrown tech firms and lead to a “splinternet,” he said.You end up with two separate eco-systems in cyberspace. The free world model or the Chinese surveillance model which can look very attractive to a lot of the developing world.”The former spy, who served more than  years, insisted Britain could manage the risk posed by Huawei’s current G kit.He dismissed US threats to stop intelligence sharingBritain used G as “spurious”.Boris Johnson has faced a backlash from Tory MPs calling for Huawei to be banned from Britain’s G network on security grounds.“The idea Beijing will change its ways and stop trying to export its dictatorial systemwe adopt Huawei tech is laughable,” said Neil O’Brien, a Conservative MP and founder of the China Research Group.Natos chief Jens Stoltenburg warned China was changing the global balance of power yesterday and he urged like minded countries to stand up to its bullying and coercion.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: quiz madeleine mccann suspect over joana 8 family plead
story: Joana Cipriano was eight when she went missing from Figueira, just five miles from Praia da Luz, in .Step-dad Leandro Silva has called on German and Portuguese police to investigate any links between Madeleine’s suspect and Joana.The young girl’s mum, Leonor Cipriano, and uncle, Joao Cipriano, were convicted of murdering the eight-year-old, although her body has never been found.The pair served nearly two decades in jail, but Mr Silva still claims that they are innocent.The -year-old told The Mirror: “The moment I saw police had a Madeleine suspect I thought about poor Joana and how he could be involved.“The disappearance of my step-daughter is an unresolved case, whatever the authorities say.“Her body has never been found and I know Leonor would never have hurt Joana. She was a good mum.Joana was sent out to get tuna and milk from a local shop in Figueira on the evening of September , .A neighbour spotted her about  yards from her house walking back from the shop – the last time she was seen alive.Police argued that the pair killed the eight-year-old because she had witnessed them having incestuous sex.The siblings were each jailed for  years.Mr Silva also said Christian B could hold the key to solving the disappearance.He continued: “I think the police handled the investigation so badly.“That’s why I’d like a new police team to re-examine everything and seethis German man is involved.He added: “Christian [B] is a person who should be questioned. There are still so many unanswered questions hanging over Joana’s disappearance and he could hold the key to solving them.”The convicted paedophile has been linked to a number of other child disappearances in recent days.Carola Titze, who was  when she went missing, had reportedly been in contact with a German man days before she vanished in .Meanwhile, German detectives investigating Christian B have contacted the family of missing René Hasee to say they are looking into his  abduction again.The youngster, from Elsdorf, Germany, vanished on June   while on holiday with his family in Aljezur – just  miles from Praia da Luz.He ran ahead during a family walk on the beach to go in the sea, but his loved ones never saw him again.Christian B is also being investigated over the disappearance of a girl dubbed the ‘German Maddie’.The suspect was reportedly in the same area as five-year-old Inga Gehricke when she vanished in May .The toddler had been enjoying a family BBQ in woodlands in the state of Saxony-Anhalt – around  miles from Berlin – when she vanished without a trace.Madeleine McCann was just three-years-old when she vanished in Portugal while on holiday with her family in .Christian B is currently in prison for raping a -year-old American woman in Portugal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Julian Bird, Chief Executive of UK Theatres made the bleak assessment to the DCMS committee as he called for more clarity on reopening from the government.Mr Bird said the industry needed to knowthey would be able to open for the lucrative Christmas panto season or  per cent of venues would run out of cash.He said: ”Christmas for theatres is absolutely essential… Pantomimes, Christmas musicals, Christmas shows… Its where they can make profits that they use later in the year for other productions.Its vital… Do I think its cancelled yet  I very, very much hope not.But he added that the industry needed to know what help it would get and said: ”The sector needs understanding around the support that might be available to it.We need that in a timely fashion because most theatres have to make a decision around their Christmas production by early August.He said that evensocial distancing measures were reduced to one metre, down from two, most theatres would only be able to operate at  per cent capacity which he said was “not an economic business model.” But he said there was hope that open air venues, like The Minack theatre, perched on Cornish clfs could open sooner.The Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee was also warned about the state of the music industry as a result of the pandemic.Horace Trubridge, general secretary of the Musicians Union, told MPs: All the work - live work, studio work, orchestras, everything - just fell off a clf, it all disappeared.Our members have had no income whatsoever from work since the middle of March and its had a devastating effect on the profession…Our wonderful industry is so dependent upon audiences and we cant see a point… When we will be able to put an audience in a venue to see a live performance for quite some time.Were very dferent to other areas of the economy which are poised to step forward to resume their activities. story: Chauvin has been charged with second-degree murder in the death of Floyd – a -year-old black man who died after the Minneapolis cop was seen in video kneeling on his neck.David Pinney, who worked with the men at El Nuevo Rodeo, told CBS News the pair clashed while working security at the Minneapolis venue.He said: They bumped heads.It has a lot to do with Derek being extremely aggressive within the club with some of the patrons, which was an issue.Floyd worked as a security guard inside the club while Chauvin sat in his patrol car, while off-duty, outside the venue, it has been reported.Maya Santamaria, the clubs former owner, previously said the pair had worked on the same nights, but she was unsurethe two knew each other.Santamarina told CBS News she thinks Chauvin was afraid and intimidated by black people.She said Chauvin, who worked for her for  years, often lost his temper with patrons and would pepper spray them evenI felt it was unwarranted.Last month, she told KSTP-TV that he had a real short fuse and he seemed afraid.”“When there was an altercation he always resorted to pulling out his mace and pepper spraying everybody right away, evenI felt it was unwarranted,” Santamaria added.Floyd died in May after Chauvin kneeled on his neck for nearly nine minutes during an arrest over an alleged fake bank note.Video from the incident showed Floyd saying I cant breathe multiple times – but Chauvin did not move his knee.Floyds death has sparked protests and unrest across the country as well as the world.Demonstrators have called for the end to police brutality and systemic racism as they show support for the Black Lives Matter movement.Chauvin and the three other officers involved in Floyds death are all facing charges.It was recently revealed that the disgraced cop was in talks of a plea deal with prosecutors before he was arrested.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: far right blm football storm
story: Football firms and far-right thugs have vowed to defend the nations war memorials and statues, sparking concerns of violence on Britains streets.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterIt comes after a video plea from former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson.Real name Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, he released a two-minute outburst in which he accused police of being “soft-handed” because there were “too many people who aren’t white”.He boasts a criminal record with convictions for a number of offences, including football-related violence, trying to travel on  documents and a protest against Fa’s decision to stop the England football team wearing poppies on their shirts.There are now concerns the anti-racist protests could spiral into even more clashes.Ken Marsh, chairman of the politan Police Federation, said: “There’s an awful lot of preparation going on. I have been very critical of the way this has been managed.“We have got the perfect storm ahead of us this weekend, we have got planned protests and now Tommy Robinson and his agitators.”The Democratic Football Lads Alliance, a network founded in  that claims to oppose terrorism has told members to defend statues and war memorials.Anti-fascist organisation Hope Not Hate warned of violence on British streets, claiming the group were using the protests as cover.Chief executive  Nick Lowles said: “While the group’s stated intention of protecting the war memorials might attract the sympathy of some, let us be in no doubt about their real objective — violence.It comes as:The last week saw  officers injured in the capital, including a PC who remains in hospital after being thrown from her horse in Whitehall. There were  arrests over three demonstrations.Sickening footage yesterday revealed clashes between protesters and a jeering group separated by a line of police at the rally in Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire yesterday.They can be heard yelling why dont you go back to Africa then before chanting theres only one Lee Rigby, Herts Live reports.The weekend saw thousands of anti-racism protesters gathered across the UK - with Black Lives Matter rallies in London, Manchester, Newcastle, Cardf and Watford following the death of George Floyd.Mr Floyd died after white police officer Derek Chauvin held him down by kneeling on his neck in Minneapolis on May , sparking days of protests in the US.Yesterday saw a monument to a slave trader removed from Londons docklands after the Black Lives Matter protests - as cops shielded Winston Churchills statue from further damage.The figure of Robert Milligan was taken down by a JCB from its plinth in West India Quay following a petition by a Labour MP.Tower Hamlets Council authorised the removal of the figure by professionals this evening, meanwhile cops had to form a human shield to protect a monument to Winston Churchill in parliament Square.In a statement on Twitter, the council said: “Tonight, we have removed the statue of slave trader Robert Milligan that previously stood at West India Quay.“We have also announced a review into monuments and other sites in our borough to understand how we should represent the more troubling periods in our history.”Sharing footage of the moment the statue of Robert Milligan was removed, London Mayor Sadiq Khan tweeted: The statue of slave trader Robert Milligan has now been removed from West India Quay.The Winston Churchill statue was also vandalised during the protest in Londons Parliament Square.It appears the world-famous memorial of Winston Churchill was defaced with letters ACAB - which is believed to stand for All Cops Are B******s.Pictures show police officers standing in front of the memorial with neon green graffiti defacing it on the th anniversary of D-Day, on Saturday.Police in Bristol were criticised for allowing angry protesters to tear down the statue of slavetrader Edward Colston last weekend.There are now fears that similar statues could be torn down by groups of protesters, with Black Lives Matter leaders believed to have complied a list of controversial memorials they want targeted.Mass peaceful protests also took place over a statue Cecil Rhodes at Oriel College in Oxford University this evening, as thousands called for its removal.The Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group has called for the image of the mining magnate and empire builder to be removed, saying the university has failed to address its institutional racism.On Friday, the Health Secretary Matt Hancock begged Brits not to join in, urging them to avoid mass demonstrations as they breach lockdown rules.But people have been rallying for justice in the UK all week, with thousands taking to the streets.Boxing champ Anthony Joshua was among the crowds who marched in Watford on Saturday.Protests across the US had initially been marred by the looting and destroying of shops, and videos of violence between police and crowds quickly spread on social media.However, peaceful demonstrations have now taken over.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s farms are crying out for fit and healthy temporary workers to keep them going and to help deliver the best quality fruit and veg to the UK. Pick For Britain is a national campaign, bringing workers and employers together to match skills and need to help save the farming industry. The campaign brings all recruiters and those seeking work in one place, from pickers and packers, to plant husbandry and tractor or forklt drivers. Pick for Britain is the perfect chance to pass the summer months and earn moneyyou’re a university student, a way to continue workingyou’re on furlough and a great way to meet new people and be part of an extraordinary national effort to get seasonal food on people’s plates. One British worker who has signed up to work is Lucy, who lives in London. She was travelling in sub-Saharan Africa when the coronavirus crisis began to unfold so ed home and is now doing her bit to Britain in the need for food.  She said: I’m working on one of the iceberg lettuce rigs. I’m staying on site and it’s great - really really enjoying it. it’s a great team atmosphere. You move with the rig across the field, you have to keep up with the pace that the guys are picking it at – itaposs great fun and I’m glad to be doing something useful with my time. I would % recommend it to somebody . I’m having a really good time, the people are really nice, and it’s nice to be out in the open air and doing something physical. Though the work can be demanding, farm work is currently considered key work and it’s a healthy and productive way to support local communities during this dficult time. You usually need to be at least  years old to work on a farm, but there may be roles for  to -year-olds depending on the business and for most roles previous experience is not required, with training given by the farms. Ideally farms are looking for people who can work a full working week but days and hours can y by farm and according to the weather.

title: david lammy black lives matter
story: NewsopinionDavid Lammy: Black Lives Matter protesters deserve to see action and lasting changeProtesters taking to Britains streets and toppling statues to highlight racism past and present are looking for answers not meaningless platitudes, Labour MP David Lammy writesShareCommentsByDavid Lammy MP:,  JUN NewsopinionLabour Shadow Secretary for Justice and MP for Tottenham David Lammy " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Black Lives Matter movement demands action, not just rhetoric. Last weekend Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, said of the Black Lives Matter protests: “Thankfully, this is all based in response to events in America rather than here.” This betrayed an attitude of arrogance, complacency and ignorance. Of course, the brutal murder of George Floyd triggered this moment of mass protest: first in the US and then across the world. But it has only gathered the momentum in this country, because prejudice, bias and, yes, racism, exists on this side of the Atlantic, too. Labour does not support how the protesters pulled down the statue of Edward Colston, but it should have been removed democratically a long time ago. Colston, who smuggled more than , men, women and children out of Africa to be sold as slaves, does not deserve to be memorialised in Bristol. The fact that there is even a debate shows there are issues around race in our own society.

story: NewsRadical idea to give every British adult £, a year - at a priceThe respected Royal Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce suggests the cash payment - but it would replace the current personal allowance in Income TaxShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsThe report suggests £, for every citizen" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEvery British adult should be handed £, a year in a radical overhaul of the tax and benefit a system, a report says today. The plan would replace the current personal allowance and help to form a “a modern safety net for all”, according to a report by the RSA think tank. It could rise to a £, universal basic income combined with other benefits, the study says,The idea is among a series of recommendations from the report, A Blueprint for Good Work, by the RSA Future Work Centre – and comes as the economy is braced for a devastating recession triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.Others include replacing JobCentres with Swedish-style “job security councils” to help workers in troubled sectors like retail, where roles risk being taken over by computers or robots.  It also calls for employees in major firms to have stronger voices over new technology and restructuring, through “democratic works councils”, as happens in Germany. Sick pay, holiday entitlement and pensions should be available to gig economy workers through a “portable benefits” system so they have the same access as contracted workers, the study adds. Future Work Centre head Alan Lockey said: Tackling economic insecurity is essential to securing Britain’s recovery.  “That means getting cash to people now by turning the personal allowance into a universal cash payment, targeted help for the most troubled sectors, giving workers a greater say over new tech, stronger unions, and a new welfare settlement for gig economy workers. “The conversation about how we build a better future beyond the pandemic must begin now – we already know the furlough scheme will end in October. “The crisis can lead to positive change, but we need to be bold.” The report also calls for government, opposition parties, employers and unions, to forge a new “social contract”. Shadow Cabinet Office Minister Rachel Reeves said: Now, more than ever, we need a vision for a new social contract, built around social justice, good work, and security for all.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Locked out schoolchildren and their families need a planThe Government has conceded schoolchildren wont be back in classrooms by summer and now it needs to tell families how their kids will get the education they deserveShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JUN Newsopinion " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Government must produce a radical plan for as many as nine million pupils facing up to six months locked out of school thanks to coronavirus. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson dismissed the fears of teachers and parents about an earlyand now looks foolish after rethinking his position. He’s axed plans for primary kids in England to be back by summer and is effectively conceding defeat in the secondary section. The Daily Mirror’s consistently pressed for classes to resume, but only when safe. Children who spread colds to their families could do the same with the virus. We need a timetable to enable pupils missing out to catch up. It might include summer lessons, personalised tuition and extra classes from autumn on. What is certain is education can no longer be run on a shoestring. Our children deserve the best. Let’s give it to them. Who to honour The toppling of slave trader Edward Colston’s statue in Bristol has started a much-needed debate on who should be honoured in our towns and cities. However figures should be removed by local consent rather than by a crowd doing it themselves. But this discussion is long overdue.Just because a statue was erected in the past doesn’t mean it must stay forever. So let’s start a national conversation about who stands on plinths in public places, including who should replace the removed.  Why not some working class heroes  Bristol could honour local Paul Stephenson who led a successful bus boycott in the s to overturn a ban on black drivers and conductors.
