title: alarming increase in number of children using foodbank
story: The coronavirus pandemic has caused an “alarming” increase in the number of children relying on support from the Lerwick foodbank.April saw a  per cent spike in demand for food parcels for youngsters compared with the same month last year.The increase from  to  has been put down to children staying at home during the lockdown, putting a strain on family budgets at exactly the same time that many parents are unable to go out to work.Overall, the foodbank saw a  per cent increase in demand.The Scottish government has announced £. million in support to help tackle food insecurity –  a move welcomed by the foodbank co-ordinator David Grieve.However, he said the Covid- crisis was having a dramatic impact on demand for services, particularly for youngsters.That was something Mr Grieve has described as “alarming”.“The number of children who were receiving help in April this year was  per cent higher than in April ,” he said.Foodbank co-ordinator David Grieve. Photo: Dave Donaldson“Much of this increase in demand is likely to be because children are at home all day and every day, putting more demands on family budgets for food, electricity, heating and more.“Similarly parents are probably not working either and so are also at home adding to the financial strain.”Overall, the national picture has seen demand for foodbank stocks rise by  per cent in April, with a  per cent rise for children.Mr Grieve said: “The foodbank is coping well with the rise in demand. Food stocks are good, helped by food coming in from both the Scottish government through the council hub and from the national support effort organised by Tesco.“These two sources have really helped to boost our normal regular food donations coming in through local shops.“Where necessary we have also been able to buy in additional food and toiletries using the funds which we have received from many dferent sources.”SIC education and families committee chairman George Smith said the figures were “concerning” and urged anyone who thought they may be entitled to free school meals to make the necessary enquiries.Mr Smith said: “It’s obviously concerning and disappointing that there is an increased demand on the foodbank particularly from families.George Smith: #There are probably people accessing the foodbank who have never had to do so in the past#“There are probably people accessing the foodbank that have never had to do so in the past.“I would encourage anybody entitled to free school meals to be making sure they make that application“We are paying £ a day, and that goes into the bank account.”Mr Smith’s comments came as the Scottish government highlighted additional support it was providing from its £ million Food Fund.FareShare, a national network of charitable food distributors, has distributed over , tonnes of food – the equivalent of almost . million meals – since rd March, supported by £, of Scottish government funding.Now, an additional £. million of funding will help FareShare purchase more food for local authorities, community-run initiatives and frontline charities across Scotland.Mr Grieve said: “This is very welcome news as Shetland has been benefiting from the government’s support following the announcement of the initial £, funding and I fully expect that the need for this support will remain for many months to come, even when the pandemic is fully controlled.“The Trussell Trust announced today that nationally there has been an  per cent increase in demand for support during April compared with  and more alarmingly there was a  per cent rise in support for children.”Scottish communities minister Aileen Campbell said: “At this dficult time, it is more important than ever that we tackle food insecurity by supporting the work of community food distribution groups across the country who are best placed to ensure vital supplies reach those who need it most.“By working in partnership with FareShare and their partners in communities across Scotland, this extra funding will help frontline charities and community food groups provide support to even more people in need.” raquoWe were told there was no magic money tree. Services for the most vulnerable were slashed. Yet we could afford to cut tax for the highest earners in . Food banks have become normalised. This is not normal. This is not inevitable. We could choose as a society to look after our most vulnerable so they are not reduced to this. We could easily afford to. Once this is over, we need to do better. I don#t know how # but I know a man who does# Ian over to you ..

title: lerwick chocolate shop mirrie dancers to close
story: In a post on Facebook, business owner Dave Williams said it was with a heavy heart that the decision had been taken. It is part of the company#s plans to #ersy our locations# and open a new shop in the Highlands.Mirrie Dancers was formed in  when its first shop in Lerwick was opened. It later moved into premises next to the Market Cross in the heart of the town.In , the business expanded opening a new store in Kirkwall. The Orkney shop is being retained before the hoped-for expansion into the Highlands.As we start to come out of lockdown, I wanted to let you know that we will be changing where we are based.For some#Mr Williams wrote on Facebook that the impact of the coronavirus crisis had forced some changes.#Unfortunately, this means that we will not be re-opening our shop in Shetland. It is with a heavy heart we are leaving the town where my dream began, and our lovely little shop on the market square, but focusing on those who have worked with us the longest is the best decision for us right now.#He also praised the friendship and support he had experienced in Shetland.#Finally, I just want to say a massive thank you to everyone for your warm welcome to the islands, the incredible support as friends and fellow businesses. I will miss you!# raquo..

title: more shetland shops and services expected to reopen next week as scotland approaches phase two of route map out of lockdown
story: More shops, services and leisure facilities will be hoping to reopen in Shetland next week after the First Minister said she was #optimistic# about moving into the next phase out of lockdown.Nicola Sturgeon said yesterdaythat when the next formal review arrives – next Thursday – she hoped to progress to phase two of the route map #with more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to reopen and operate again#.Ms Sturgeon made the announcement as part of her lunchtime briefing, which heard that for the second day running no new deaths had been reported for people who had tested positive for Covid-.#This is obviously very encouraging,# she said.#I can’t tell how much I have longed to report such a development – and I know you will have longed to hear that.#But even so, we must still exercise caution. We know from previous weeks that fewer deaths tend to be registered at weekends – so it is still highly likely that more Covid deaths will be recorded in the days ahead. But I very much hope we continue to see a steady decline.#Shetland#s official number of Covid- cases has now remained unchanged at  for seven weeks, since th April.Authorities in the isles have said previously they felt it necessary to stick with the national approach to easing lockdown.Ms Sturgeon announced the route map out of lockdown last month, with Scotland entering phase one on th May.The next formal review takes place on Thursday, th June, meaning phase two could take effect from the th.Phase two allows people to meet outside with larger groups, including from other households, with physical distancing and hygiene measures.People will be able to drive locally for leisure and public transport is planned to increase services, though still at signicantly reduced capacity.The route map states there may be #geographical dferences# in approaches to transport, depending on circumstances.More shops will be able to reopen, with physical distancing in place, as well as outdoor markets.Pubs and restaurants will be able to open outdoor spaces with physical distancing and increased hygiene routines. Few Shetland pubs and restaurants have outdoor spaces, however, meaning not all will be able to reopen.Playgrounds and sports courts are also expected to reopen as well as places of worship for private prayer, marriages and civil partnerships and other ceremonies but with limited numbers of attendees.Health boards are expected to increase the provision to meet the backlog of demand, urgent referrals and the triage of routine services.Vulnerable groups, who had been told to shield until th June, have been told they should continue until st July – although they will be advised that outdoor exercise is permissible.#I know that many of you listening today will be very disappointed that shielding is to continue for some time yet, Ms Sturgeon said.#I want to assure you though that this is not a decision we take lightly – it weighs heavily on all of us, including on me.But it is for your protection. And I hope that our advice on exercise, should it come into force next week as I expect, will make a dference for many of you.Ms Sturgeon urged everyone to stick with the guidelines.#These painful but necessary sacrices have brought us to where we are today – with this virus in retreat,# she said.#In retreat, but not gone. And still posing a real risk, especially to the most clinically vulnerable.#And that’s the key point I want to make to you today. This is such a crucial juncture in our battle against the virus. We will either keep going, keep beating it back – or we will give it the chance to roar back with a vengeance.# raquo

title: student calls for isles to play active role in stamping out racism
story: A student is writing to public bodies serving the isles as part of an effort to ensure Shetland plays an active role in giving racism the boot.Fraser Tait is contacting Shetland Islands Council#s chief executive with a call for a four-pronged approach to ensure the chances of any improper attitudes or behaviour gaining a foothold in the isles are immediately stamped out.The  year-old scholar of Edinburgh University has already gathered over  signatures to his open letter to Maggie Sandison, and is hopeful of attracting more.He also intends to dispatch the letter to NHS Shetland and local police representatives.Mrs Sandison has insisted robust measures are in place within the council and insisted there is no place for racism within the authority.It follows the launch of a local organisation in support of the pressure group Black Lives Matter, which has gained momentum in light of the international outrage over the death of George Floyd. this weekend.Mr Tait, a former pupil at Sandwick Junior High School, says he wants Shetland to:• Put in place zero tolerance#I decided to write a letter because I had seen open letters written by black students at university and felt this was a good way to voice concerns over racism and also show a good public backing behind the comments I made,# he said.#I#m also a key worker at the moment, so I didn#t want to attend a protest and risk public safety.#I chose to write an open letter to Maggie Sandison because she is chief executive of the SIC and following her rapid and efficient response to Covid-, she seems to have the concern for Shetland citizens at the forefront of her mind when making decisions and so would be likely to listen.#That#s not to say other people wouldn#t, but she is in a position of power in Shetland and would be a powerful ally to have in the fight against racism here.#But Mr Tait has not sent the letter to Mrs Sandison as yet. He hopes to compile more signatures before sending it to the council chief.He insists policies aimed at addressing racism must be upheld.#It’s one thing to have it written on paper but another to actually act on the prejudice and racism within our local community.#Maggie Sandison the council was #fully committed# to working under the terms of the Equality Act  to promote equality and inclusiveness.#I haven’t received a copy of the letter yet but I welcome that iniduals and our community are uniting to fight racism and injustice,# she said.#The council promotes participation and the empowerment of people as citizens to be more involved in shaping the future of our community and the services the council provides to the community.#The council is committed to fulfilling its duties under the Equalities Act . The council promotes equality and inclusion in its organisational policies and considers the impacts on equality of all its decisions.#Any form of racism, discrimination or hate speech isn’t welcome. Our values are about ersity, inclusivity and tolerance, and it is everyone’s personal responsibility to take a stand against racism and other inequality issues.#Our HR policies are designed to promote a culture and environment of equality of opportunity and to actively prevent discrimination, harassment and victimisation.#She added: #Racism would be a disciplinary offence in the council’s code of conduct for staff and would be reported to the police as a possible hate crime.# raquo..

title: viking to begin cautious construction work on kergord track
story: Construction work on Viking Energy#s Kergord access track is set to resume next week.Work has been halted on the project for almost three months, but Viking has said that #cautious# work will now begin again from Monday th June.Local contractor Tulloch Developments are set to carry out construction on the . mile access track, with #strict controls# now in place due to coronavirus.Viking say that #stringent# health and safety measures have been introduced to protect staff working on the access track, although they did not say what measures would be in place.Work on these projects is permitted under the latest Scottish Government coronavirus guidance, Viking has said.The track will give SSEN access to a proposed electricity converter station, which forms part of the -turbine windfarm project.It is hoped that the track will now be completed in the #autumn months#, with work originally due to be finished in July...

title: litir do luchd ionnsachaidh
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine..Bha an cunntas agam mu mhurt Dhòmhnaill mhic Uilleim ann an sgìre Chnoc Mhoire faisg air a’ Mhanachainn. Dh’fhàg am murtair, Iain mac ʼan Mhòir, agus a bhràthair-chèile, Iain MacCoinnich, a bha cuideachd ciontach, corp Dhòmhnaill air a’ chladach.Anns an sgìre sin, chan eil an sruth mara uabhasach làidir. Trì latha an dèidh a’ mhuirt, lorg cìobair an corp. Chaidh a chur don eaglais ann an Cnoc Mhoire. Dh’iarr an siorram, Alasdair Siosalach, air a h-uile inbheach anns an sgìre nochdadh aig an eaglais. Bha eadar sia ceud is seachd ceud duine ann.Bha corp Dhòmhnaill rùisgte, air dèile. Nuair a leugh an siorram ainm gach duine, bha aige no aice ri tighinn air adhart, air beulaibh a h-uile duine eile, agus làmh a chur air broilleach Dhòmhnaill. Bha an siorram an dòchas nach cleitheadh am murtair a chiont anns an t-suidheachadh sin.. Chuir e a làmh air broilleach a’ ghille, agus thachair rudeigin annasach. Dh’fhosgail lot air broilleach Dhòmhnaill, agus thàinig fuil às. Chaidh iarraidh air Iain a làmh a chur air a’ chorp dàrna turas. Rinn e sin, agus ruith fuil à sròn a’ chuirp. e a chiont. Mhothaich daoine nach robh sgeul air Iain MacCoinnich. Thàinig aithris gum facas e aig drochaid Inbhir Nis, agus e a’ ceannach tombaca. An uair sin, dh’fhalbh e rathad Shrath Narann.’ ann am Beurla. Bha e an sin, fliuch is fuar, airson ceala-deug. Mu dheireadh, thuit a dhà chois dheth, mar gun robh lannsair air an gearradh dheth. Ghabh cuid truas ris – agus cuimhnichibh nach robh e air am murt aideachadh.Chaidh Iain a thoirt dhachaigh gu Fionn Ghasg. Mean air mhean, dh’fhàs e na bu làidire. Bha e eadhon comasach air coiseachd air na stùmpaichean coise aige. Chuir a nàbaidhean airgead ri chèile, agus cheannaich iad each dha. Cha robh e comasach air obair a dhèanamh. Bha e na dhèirceach.Ge-tà, chaidh Iain MacCoinnich a lorg. Bha e a’ fuireach ann am Baile Chè fon ainm ‘Dòmhnall Gàidhealach’. Chaidh a chur an grèim. ʼS ann nuair a chunnaic e seann Eaglais Inbhir Nis a dh’aidich e a chiont. Dh’inns e gur e Iain mac ʼan Mhòir a bu choireach ris a’ mhurt.Chaidh an dà Iain a chur air beulaibh britheamh. Fhuair am britheamh ciontach iad. Bha an cinn gu bhith air an gearradh dhiubh, agus air an sealltainn don phoball. Ri taobh na h-eaglaise ann an Cnoc Mhoire, bha ceann Iain MhicCoinnich agus làmh dheas Iain mhic ʼan Mhòir air an cur air pòla.Bha an cunntas dhen ghnothach air a dhèanamh le pears-eaglais. Aig an deireadh, sgrìobh e: ‘ʼS ann mar sin a bha lagh Dhè air a chur an gnìomh – Ge b’ e a dhòirteas fuil duine, le duine dòirtear fhuil-san.’* * * * *tractar Sheonaidh Phàdraig Bhig.The West Highland Free Press online shop is taking no new orders until st May .Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

title: ross shire skye and lochalsh womens aid are here for
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineRoss-shire Skye and Lochalsh Women’s Aid provides services to women, children, and young people in the Ross-shire, Skye, and Lochalsh areas that are experiencing, or have experienced, the effects of domestic abuse. It is one of  local Women’s Aid groups across Scotland..  : “More than ever we need people to be aware that we have a service available in Skye and although we might not be able to meet with you face to face at this moment in time we are at the end of the telephone. If you need to speak to someone phone us. #A window for women to seek help is extremely limited but during periods of isolation this window narrows further. #If you are a family member, friend, or neighbour with concerns about someone phone us and let us know and we will do our best to help the person.#The challenges of offering a service like ours in Skye and Lochalsh can be dficult at the best of times but with the impact of Covid-, we still want to emphasise that this is not a service that should be ignored. #We have specialist staff who are equipped to help youyou are experiencing domestic abuse.#It is also important to stress that Covid- is not causing domestic abuse, an abuser causes domestic abuse, there is no excuse for abuse at any time!” The West Highland Free Press online shop is taking no new orders until st May .Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

title: criomagan uist pupils find elderly pen pals msp to stand down corncrakes and ceolas
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoinePrimary School Pupils in Uist have been writing letters to a number of befriending networks on the island to help support people during lockdown.The children were also aware of elderly community members and decided to write to them as they knew they would appreciate a friendly letter during the lockdown period.The pupils of Sgoil Uibhist a Tuath, Sgoil Bhaile a# Mhanaich, Sgoil an Iochdair and Sgoil Dhalabroig were encouraged to write letters to people living in care homes as part of the National Literacy Trust Dear New Friend initiative.However, as the children have built relationships with a number of inter-generational groups throughout the islands, the schools took the initiative one step further and focused on writing to a number of befriending networks already established in Uist including Caraidean Uibhist, Tagsa and Cuimhne.One Sgoil Bhaile a# Mhanaich pupil became aware of a Benbecula woman stranded in Australia and wrote a Gaelic letter to her knowing that a letter in her mother tongue would comfort her while away from home.Seasoned campaigner and veteran politician, Highlands and Islands Labour MSP David Stewart, is to retire at the next Scottish Parliament election at the age of .Mr Stewart is one of a small band of Scottish politicians who have served as a councillor, an MP and an MSP.He became the first Labour MP to represent the previous constituency of Inverness East, Nairn and Lochaber in , doubling his majority in  before losing his seat to Lib-Dem Danny Alexander in .In  he re-entered politics as a Highlands and Islands Labour MSP on the regional list, and was elected for a further two terms, the latest ending next year at the election. In fact, Mr Stewart will be  the day before polling day.For me retiring is a bitter sweet moment,” said Mr Stewart.“I’ve been dedicated to politics and the Labour Party for most of my le. I’ve met thousands of people, worked cross-party with countless politicians, been on the doorstep with many activists for Westminster and Scottish Parliament elections and I don’t regret a moment of it.“It’s been a privilege to serve Inverness and the Highlands and Islands throughout my career but it’s time to move over for new blood.”Ceòlas Uibhist will mark the  summer school, which was cancelled due to the Covid- outbreak, with a virtual An Cèilidh Mòr on Friday,  July at pm.The concert, which will feature past and present tutors from the school, will premiere on Facebook and Youtube.Ceòlas will set up a page for donations.Throughout June, highlights of past summer school concerts from the Ceòlas archive will be posted on Ceòlas’ social media accounts weekly.RSPB staff have been receiving a large number of reports of corncrakes this year during the lockdown from people in the local community who have been excited to hear the birds from their houses and crofts.The RSPS are appeal for further sightings and reports from the local community to help us with survey numbers.Corncrakes have been in decline across Scotland over the last few years, but the Hebrides continue to be the UK stronghold for the species, with a small population also present at Durness on the mainland.Corncrakes are particularly susceptible to early cutting of silage fields which can destroy nests and chicks.Please contact one of the following RSPB staffyou hear a corncrake in your area or would like advice on habitat management for the species. Skye: Shelagh.parlane@rspb.org.uk Uist: Jamie.boyle@rspb.org.uk Lewis and Harris: Shona.Morrison@rspb.org.uk Durness: Catherine.Owen-Pam@rspb.org.ukThe West Highland Free Press online shop is taking no new orders until st May .Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

title: orange order promotes 12th at home plan with barbecues and radio boyne
story: PEOPLE in Ballymena and Antrim have been urged to take part in ‘lockdown’ th celebrations - in their own homes and gardens.The Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland last week formally announced its plans to celebrate the th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne.With traditional Twelfth of July demonstrations cancelled due to the Coronavirus pandemic, the Orange Institution has instead laid on plans for a ‘th at Home’.A four-day programme will run from Friday, th of July, through to Monday, th of July and will take place under a simple mantra - celebrate the day online, in your home or at your door.Grand Master Most Wor. Bro. Edward Stevenson has appointed Deputy Grand Master Wor. Bro Harold Henning to oversee events.Bro. Henning commented: “Just because our parades and gatherings may be cancelled – the  Twelfth isn’t! King William’s momentous and symbolic victory at the Boyne  years ago will most certainly still be celebrated and commemorated in a number of ways by the Orange family.”There will be a wide range of activities and resources available on the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland website - goli.org.uk thathome - specially designed to ensure all members of the Orange Family can enjoy the long weekend.The cornerstone of this special celebration will be ‘Radio Boyne’ featuring four days of digital broadcasting which can be accessed through the Grand Lodge websitewhen it goes live on the th July. It is anticipated that a range of guest interviews, music, news and history programming will be featured.The broad focus will be on activities for all the family. A section has been created on the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland website with colouring, crafts, recipes and other ideas to help make your ‘th at Home’ a success.The traditional elements of the Twelfth of July demonstrations, including the reading of the resolutions and the religious service will be broadcast online, both through Facebook and the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland’s YouTube channel. Acts of remembrance, such as laying wreaths, will also be covered. The Grand Chaplains will be preparing a special prayer to be read out on the day. There will also be a Boyne Annual Divine Service online on Sunday, th of July.The Deputy Grand Master has encouraged families to start planning for their ‘th at Home’ now. “Our challenge is to ensure this Twelfth is marked in style online, in your home, at your door, with families and neighbours. Together we can make it a fun-filled, extra-special - socially distanced th - that will be talked about for years,” he explained. “The Grand Lodge website seeks to support and resource the Boyne Anniversary Celebrations. There is something for everyone: craft and colouring pages for the young and recipes for your th night Barbecue.“So, begin by planning to suitably decorate your home, street, village or town - fly the flag, proudly and respectfully. Encourage children and grandchildren to watch our craft videos and create Orange Lilies and bunting or brush up your history by reading about William’s Generals.”Bro. Henning also highlighted the need for all celebrations to respect and adhere to the social distancing guidelines in place to prevent the spread of Coronavirus.He added: “During our celebrations let us be mindful that the priority in  is to look after everyone’s health this Twelfth as we continue the battle against Coronavirus. Please ensure you comply with the lockdown regulations in existence over the period.”

title: the star attraction professor brian cox for ballymena event
story: BALLYMENA is to host the first Northern Ireland Science School – hosted by Professor Brian Cox OBE, the acclaimed physicist and BBC presenter.The Science School, backed by Mid and East Antrim Council, is aimed at inspiring the next generation of scientists and innovators. It will take place on November  in conjunction with leading educators and influencers from across the STEAMsectors.Young people attending the event in November will hear from industry and academic leaders at the forefront of the STEAM sector, and from the famous physicist and astronomer Professor Cox, who will deliver the keynote address.Teenage environmental champions, Amy and Ella Meek, will also speak about how their mission to make a dference by reducing plastic pollution, has seen them create an award-winning charity which has inspired children, business leaders and politicians throughout the UK.Professor Cox will also lead an evening  session for students, parents and special guests from across Northern Ireland to hear more about the STEAM Career Pathways available to them.The Science Summer Schools initiative was established in  at St Paul’s Way Trust School in East London by Lord Andrew Mawson OBE and Professor Cox. It is now being expanded nationally on a year-round basis in partnership with entrepreneurial community business Well North Enterprises.The collective aim is to make ‘the UK the best place to do science’. The future need for more scientists and engineers nationally has been highlighted as a priority by the current Coronavirus pandemic.Lord Mawson OBE said: “This is an appropriate time to be bringing the first Science School hosted by Professor Cox to Ballymena!“Science and the desire to learn more about how our world works, and about how we can use that information to improve how we live our lives, has never been more attractive or relevant as a subject area and a potential career path.”Professor Brian Cox OBE added: “The Coronavirus pandemic vividly illustrates the importance of understanding the natural world a perfect definition of science.“The solutions will come in the form of effective treatments and a vaccine. These will be found because of the understanding we have of viruses, genetics and our immune system built up over many years.“A great deal of this knowledge was acquired by scientists who were simply curious about how Nature works. In that statement there is a lesson and a reason for hope.“Curiosity is a powerful thing, and science is about harnessing curiosity and honing it into the best method we have for acquiring new knowledge and exploring the unknown.“That’s what science is all about, and that’s why we need you to become the scientists of the future! I look forward to seeing you in Northern Ireland in November!”Mayor of Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, Cllr Maureen Morrow, said:“Council is delighted to be working with local businesses, schools, universities and partner organisations to bring this exciting opportunity to the borough.”

title: nominate covid heroes for recognition
story: THE Mayor of Mid and East Antrim is calling for nominations of local volunteers, charities and organisations who have in some way helped during Covid- so he can recognise their support.Councillor Peter Johnston will present those who are nominated with a certicate of recognition for their dedication to helping others during the Covid- crisis.The Mayor took the opportunity to acknowledge the remarkable effort during Volunteers Week which runs from June -.He said local volunteers should be celebrated in the same way as frontline workers during the current crisis.“Since the beginning of the COVID- emergency Mid and East Antrim’s Community and Voluntary sector has gone above and beyond and a huge number of volunteers have been incredible in their community response.“People have been so generous with their time and have really rallied to support their local communities through the delivery of a wide range of services.“This is a dficult time for everyone, and to see such compassion and kindness really demonstrates the strength of community spirit in Mid and East Antrim.I am delighted to have this opportunity in my first week as Mayor to extend my thanks to all local volunteers.”To nominate a group, charity or organisation email Mayors.Office@midandeastantrim.gov.uk

title: love in the air again as ni couples get go ahead to wed but ceremonies limited to
story: Aoe Lavery and Damien McCannyLisa Rea and Josh Williamson FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappAoe Lavery and Damien McCannyLauren HarteTwitterEmailJune   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFor many weeks, couples in Northern Ireland have been left wonderingwedding bells will ring for them this summer.Their plans to tie the knot were left up in the air due to the coronavirus lockdown.But now their shattered dreams have been replaced with renewed anticipation, as from Monday small outdoor weddings can take place in Northern Ireland with up to  people present.Were it not for the current Covid- pandemic, Northern Ireland would be at the height of wedding season but the latest easing of restrictions means it could still be a summer of love for many.Aoe Laveryfrom Bangor and Damien McCannyfrom Sion Mills were due to marry on May  in Portrush Town Hall in front of  family and friends.Just last Friday they finalised their replacement wedding for this Thursday at Harry#s Shack in Portstewart - a humanist ceremony with just Damien#s brother Paul and sister-in-law Claire as witnesses.We were just so lucky that Harry#s offered their outdoor decking area to couples who want to marry post-lockdown so we jumped at the chance straight away, said Aoe.Now that things are slowly getting back to normal I hope everyone who has missed out also gets their perfect day Aoe LavertyThe couple have been together for three-and-a-half years and got engaged last July.At the start of lockdown guests were getting in touch to say their flights were cancelled but then the next thing was the whole wedding was cancelled, Aoe added.In fairness we could see what was coming down the line and poor Damien was trying to manage my expectations early on and prepare me for the worst. Like everyone  we were gutted to have our original date cancelled.Having a big wedding isn#t important to us so we#re just doing it with the two of us and our witnesses on the beach. ️Now that things are slowly getting back to normal I hope everyone who has missed out also gets their perfect day.Finnebrogue Woods outside Downpatrick is another venue hoping to make  a year to remember for those still wishing to tie the knot.They include Lisa Reafrom Carryduff and her fiancé Josh Williamsonfrom Glengormley. The couple have been an item for three years and will exchange vows on June  having only got engaged on April , at the height of the lockdown.Lisa says the pair had never planned to have a long engagement or a large ceremony so the latest easing of restrictions means their prayers have been answered.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseLisa Rea and Josh Williamson FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappLisa Rea and Josh WilliamsonThe lockdown has turned out to be the perfect time for us to get married because neither of us wanted a big wedding anyway, said Lisa. We are bringing technology to the venue and will be livestreaming the ceremony for some family members in Australia and Canada. That means anyone who wants to be part of the day who can#t physically be present can still tune in. this is likely to be the experience for some months once the pubs reopen, according to those in the industry.Establishments likely to fare best on the resumption of service are larger pubs and those with outdoor space or beer gardens.Social distancing will mean fewer punters on the premises, and that could mean price hikes.The industry will also be pushing the Executive and local authorities to allow them to enhance the outdoor experience by relaxing restrictions on the use of adjacent space. After the Republic announced bars can operate as restaurants from June , and all will be allowed to open on July , there is pressure on the Stormont Executive, which met on Monday, to reveal a timeline. It#s expected to announce further rule relaxations on Thursday.But according to some publicans, it is logical for Northern Ireland to operate in tandem with the south. While pub owners have received no advice and guidance on re-opening, they have their own thoughts on how it can happen, and what the experience will be like.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseHow pubs could work when they reopen.  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappHow pubs could work when they reopen. Pedro Donald, who owns the Sunflower and the American Bar in Belfast, said the lack of guidelines makes it dficult to plan ahead, other than knowing staff will have to keep their hands clean and sanitised, and that there will be social distancing.As far as putting structures up, including screens, we are not going to do that unless we know we need to, said Mr Donald.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePedro Donald of Sunflower Bar FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappPedro Donald of Sunflower BarHe added: We will not be doing sessions initially as they would need to be spread out and space is going to be a premium. The hospitality industry has warned that pubs and restaurants may be unable to reopenthe two metre social distancing rule is not reduced. The two metre rule will not work inside Mr Donald#s bars, both of which are small two-floor spaces, although the Sunflower also has a popular large outdoor area. If that rule remains in place, he said would be able to host about four people.Mr Donald said he will not be inviting or encouraging crowds to come to his premises, but he is not sure whether there will be a big rush to the pub. A lot of people might see how it is working, while others will want to go right back, he said. The Belfast bar owner expects to have the same number of staff, with less behind the bar but more on the door and policing the toilets.Willie Jack, owner of the Harp Bar, the Dark Horse and the Duke Of York, among other establishments, believes it makes sense for bars north and south to open at the same time, rather than potentially see pubs in Londonderry and Bundoran working on a dferent schedule.He believes Monday, July  is a sensible date as it would be better not to open on a pay day at the end of the month, a weekend, or a holiday like the Twelfth. A wet Monday or Tuesday night when there is no pressure, he said.The publican expects no standing or sitting at the bar, and customers being served at certain points then ing to their table. He noted that certain countries and the World Health Organisation have endorsed the one-metre rule.There will be no live music in his venues initially, then possibly single singer songwriters. Mr Jack expects capacity to be reduced to between  and % depending on what rules are put in place by the Executive.Prices might have to go up, he said, adding that he does not want to see customers partitioned by screens.A number of his establishments are in the Cathedral Quarter in Belfast, and he wants to work with the City Council to pedestrianise the area in the evening and at weekends. Managing taxi ranks and portable toilets will be vitalthat happens, Mr Jack added. Otherwise, staff are likely to be washing hands every half hour, using sanitiser but not wearing gloves or masks, the publicans said.On Monday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock defended the two-metre rule and said businesses may have to rely on their ingenuity to operate within the restriction. He said the rule was under review, but, ultimately, it isn#t the rule that#s the challenge to the opening of hospitality in a safe way, it#s the virus. And in the Republic, Business Minister Heather Humphreys said yesterday that the two-metre rule may be changed provided that coronavirus figures go in the right direction and the transmission rate remains low. title: northern ireland firms moving jobs to republic due to brexit mp told
story: Extension call: Claire Hanna FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsappExtension call: Claire HannaLauren HarteTwitterEmailJune   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA former Northern Ireland Secretary has warned that companies here are moving jobs to the Republic because of Brexit.Julian Smith also urged Cabinet Office Minister Penny Mordaunt to look at the fact that many businesses have not realised the consequences of coming out of the single market and the customs union. We can start preparing them for that reality.He added: On the Northern Ireland protocol, there are businesses reporting to me that they are now moving jobs to the Republic.South Belfast SDLP MP Claire Hanna drew Ms Mordaunt#s attention to last week#s Assembly vote calling for an extension to the Brexit transition period.She said: The Government insisted that the Northern Ireland Assembly should have the final say on the protocol. The Assembly finally gave a say on Brexit when it voted last week to request an extension to the transition period to allow businesses, which are currently in the fight of their lives due to Covid, to adapt and to have the certainty that the minister refers to.If the Northern Ireland Assembly#s consent is so vital, should the Government not listen to what it says Ms Mordaunt said that although the Assembly would determine whether the terms of the protocol remain in force in a few years# time, the Government would not be extending the transition period.She added that trade talks with Brussels are at a key stage and need to be escalated in the coming weeks.She repeatedly ruled out extending the transition period beyond December this year and pressed the need for the UK to be treated as a sovereign equal.Mr Smith said many businesses haven#t realised the consequences of coming out of the single market and customs union. We can start preparing them for that reality, he added. Economic and social imbalances must be addressed and corrected as part of Northern Ireland’s recovery plan, says SDLP economy spokesperson Sinead McLaughlin. The Foyle MLA asked the Minister for the Economy whether she will give a commitment to the appointment of representatives from the north west to her reformed economic advisory group to assist the group in developing policies to redress existing economic imbalances. In her response, Dianne Dodds could not give that commitment. She said the Economic Advisory Group isbeing re-established to assist her in developing a new economic strategy and to provide ongoing advice on how to grow the economy. googletag.cmd.push She added that members will be appointed on the basis of their knowledge, experience and expertise, and will be expected to act andadviseon the wider Northern Ireland economy interests rather than their own sectoral or geographical interests. Sinead McLaughlin was disappointed with that response, she said: “Northern Ireland has serious inequalities and removing these must be a priority for the Department for the Economy and its minister. So I am very disappointed that the minister has rejected my requests for this to be a core part of the remit for her Economic Advisory Group and for that group to contain representatives from the North West, who could provide specialist expertise and understanding of these inequalities. googletag.cmd.push “It is unacceptable that for years, indeed decades, that Derry and the North West suffer the highest levels of unemployment and the hidden unemployment that is called economic inactivity. This must be addressed and it is astonishing to find that we are still hearing arguments that the wider economic interests of Northern Ireland are being considered without addressing the very serious problems of high unemployment and poverty that exists in the North West. “I hope that despite the minister’s response that the Economic Advisory Group will make it a priority to consider how to ensure that the parts of Northern Ireland with the highest unemployment and poverty are supported to achieve the highest levels of growth and recovery. We know from experience that in recessions it is the areas with the weakest economies that usually suffer the most. “There must be additional investment in skills and infrastructure to support the North West achieve a proper economic recovery. The Economic Advisory Group must have the courage and independence to say that and as a core part of their work to identy the sectors which offer the best prospects for increased employment, productivity and growth. It is unacceptable for Derry, Strabane and the rest of the North West to be simply told to put up with more of the same.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Under three quarters of adult club players are happy toto collective training and competitive action in the coming months, according to a survey. On Friday, the GAA released theirto action procedures, that will allow collective training from Monday, July  and competitive games to commence  days later. There has been mixed reaction over the weekend, due to safety, the ious procedures clubs would need to enforce including the appointment of a Covid Supervisor and Health Questionnaires to be completed for any activity. The County Derry Post conducted an anonymous survey yesterday with adult club players across all codes. googletag.cmd.push Over  responses – from  dferent clubs - were received, with  percent stating they had not read the extensive document outlining the guidelines for ato play. When askedthey wouldto games on July ,  percent indicating that they would do so. Eight percent said they wouldnt, with the reminder said they were unsure. The figures are almost the same for theto training date of Monday, July , with  percent of players saying they will, with  indicating they wont and rest are undecided. Some of the reasons given ranged from not being convinced social distancing would be feasible, working on the front line and the risk it would be to both themselves and their families. googletag.cmd.push One response said that amateur players should not be playing during a global pandemic. The final question on the survey was directed at one of the greatest talking points in recent weeks, whether the GAA shouldve wiped out the entire season. Of the replies,  percent felt the season shouldve been cancelled,  percent had the view that county activity should cease to allow clubs a better window. The remainderwere content with the GAAs stance. Ballerin manager Brian Deighan commended the GAA for their handling of the lockdown, but felt there was now an element of rush with an element of risk. He admits that there is a dference of opinion within his squad, which never exceeds  players. “The younger lads dont see the risk, but older lads in certain jobs or with family members in certain jobs arent keen on it . As a management team, we are dead against it...it is either safe to play or it isnt.” Brian continues by pointing to a comment he saw on social media over the weekend. “Mickey Donnelly hit the nail on the head with a tweet at the weekend, a small club will struggle to resource all these protocols and tests.” Derry CCC are set to finalise their club championship arrangements this week, following meetings to explore the options. Nothing has been confirmed, but they structures are likely to change to allow club players at least one championship game. RELATED - The GAAsto action explained. More... Under three quarters of adult club players are happy toto collective training and competitive action in the coming months, according to a survey. On Friday, the GAA released theirto action procedures, that will allow collective training from Monday, July  and competitive games to commence  days later. There has been mixed reaction over the weekend, due to safety, the ious procedures clubs would need to enforce including the appointment of a Covid Supervisor and Health Questionnaires to be completed for any activity. The County Derry Post conducted an anonymous survey yesterday with adult club players across all codes. googletag.cmd.push Over  responses – from  dferent clubs - were received, with  percent stating they had not read the extensive document outlining the guidelines for ato play. When askedthey wouldto games on July ,  percent indicating that they would do so. Eight percent said they wouldnt, with the reminder said they were unsure. The figures are almost the same for theto training date of Monday, July , with  percent of players saying they will, with  indicating they wont and rest are undecided. Some of the reasons given ranged from not being convinced social distancing would be feasible, working on the front line and the risk it would be to both themselves and their families. googletag.cmd.push One response said that amateur players should not be playing during a global pandemic. The final question on the survey was directed at one of the greatest talking points in recent weeks, whether the GAA shouldve wiped out the entire season. Of the replies,  percent felt the season shouldve been cancelled,  percent had the view that county activity should cease to allow clubs a better window. The remainderwere content with the GAAs stance. Ballerin manager Brian Deighan commended the GAA for their handling of the lockdown, but felt there was now an element of rush with an element of risk. He admits that there is a dference of opinion within his squad, which never exceeds  players. “The younger lads dont see the risk, but older lads in certain jobs or with family members in certain jobs arent keen on it . As a management team, we are dead against it...it is either safe to play or it isnt.” Brian continues by pointing to a comment he saw on social media over the weekend. “Mickey Donnelly hit the nail on the head with a tweet at the weekend, a small club will struggle to resource all these protocols and tests.” Derry CCC are set to finalise their club championship arrangements this week, following meetings to explore the options. Nothing has been confirmed, but they structures are likely to change to allow club players at least one championship game. RELATED - The GAAsto action explained. More... A County Derry woman has raised over pound, for a cancer charity by raffling a framed jigsaw that she completed at home during lockdown. Angela Kirkpatrick, who has Apert Syndrome, set about the task after she was challenged by Declan Kearney and his family, who she has lived with since her mother, Alice, died in . “Lockdown has made things more dficult for Angela,” explained Declan. “She is all about routine, so Michelle ordered a -piece jigsaw of Times Square off the internet to keep her occupied. “A few days went by and she only had fteen pieces built, and she was getting a bit frustrated, so I said to her, ‘seeyou can get that jigsaw finished, we’re going to raffle it.’ googletag.cmd.push “She spent seven or eight hours a day, for two weeks at that jigsaw. She did every bit herself and when it was finished, I got my da to frame it and put glass on the front.” Angela wanted to donate any money raised from the raffle to Marie Curie, in memory of her mother, and the prize was won by Emma, Mary and Stephen McAllister, from her hometown of Swatragh. “When I said about raffling it, she had askedwe could do it for Marie Curie, so she put it up on Facebook at pound a ticket on the Saturday night at  o’clock,” said Declan. googletag.cmd.push “The following Sunday then, we did the draw and we raised pound, altogether. Both Mid Ulster District Council and Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council have opened online books of condolence after the death in police custody of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Opening the book in Causeway Coast and Glens was outgoing mayor Sean Bateson’s final act as he relinquished the role at Monday night’s AGM. Chair of Mid Ulster Council, Cathal Mallaghan, said the book was available for anyone who ‘feels something’ in the wake of Floyd’s death. “Racism is a real virus that lives in our communities and we should be doing everything we can to stamp it out,” he said. “Normally, books of condolence would be open across our normal arts centres, but because of the Covid- restrictions, we will do it online. googletag.cmd.push “I encourage everybody who feels something about this tragic case to get online and use this as a tool to express how you feel.” The death of George Floyd has sparked anti-racism protests across the globe, with protests held locally in Belfast and Derry over the weekend. The books of condolence can be signed online via the Mid Ulster and Causeway Coast and Glens websites. googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: 340 jobs boost as Finnebrogue plans £63m facility investment
story: DOWN District is in line for a signicant jobs boost.One of Northern Irelandrsquos leading food producers has unveiled ambitious plans for a new poundm facility that will be developed in two phases, creating  jobs at the Down Business Park in Downpatrick.The award-winning Finnebrogue Artisan is initially seeking planning permission for a , square metre facility just a short distance from its current base at the business park on the outskirts of the town.Last week, a virtual community consultation event on the first phase of the proposed development mdash estimated at poundm mdash was held ahead of a formal planning application being submitted.Finnebrogue Artisan already employs around  staff with its new food production facility set to take the number of employees over the , mark, making the firm one of the largest in Northern Ireland.The new facility is designed to expand food production to allow the local firm to cater for a signicant increase in demand for its products.As the food producerrsquos proposal is deemed a major development, community consultation has to be carried out before the formal planning application is submitted.But due to the coronavirus pandemic, a virtual consultation event had to be held to provide people with an opportunity to have their say so their views could be taken into account before the schemersquos design is finalised.Last weekrsquos virtual event featured video and audio presentations from those leading the multi-million pound project, planning drawings and other documentation, with people prompted to ask questions, submit queries or ask for further information.In March, the Downpatrick business unveiled plans to recruit several hundred new temporary staff to help it respond to a signicant increase in demand as a result of the global pandemic and meet a new weekly fresh food production target of  tonnes.Downpatrick councillor, Dermot Curran, has praised Finnebrogue Artisan for its latest investment and hopes that the new factory proposal will secure planning approval.ldquoWe are fortunate to have this award-winning company in our area andthe new factory gets the green light, Finnebrogue will be employing over , people which will make it one of Northern Irelandrsquos largest employers, he said.ldquoThe companyrsquos success is driven by its innovation and food produced locally is sold in shops all across the UK.Cllr Curran said Finnebrogue Artisan has experienced phenomenal growth, creating jobs and driving forward the economy, with the latest investment proposal yet another vote of confidence in the area and its people.He added: ldquoFinnebrogue Artisan is enjoying unparalleled success due to the drive, commitment and enthusiasm of its owner and dedicated staff, with the companyrsquos innovation continually producing new and exciting products.The public has until this Friday, June , to provide feedback on the Finnebrogue Artisan proposal via email to seamus.fay.@rpsgroup or by post to Finnebrogue New production Facility, Seamus Fay, RPS, Elmwood House,  Boucher Road, Belfast. BT RZ..prettyPhoto

title: Amateur dramatics in the Forties as local artists tread the boards
story: BACK in  in a sitting room of an austere building somewhere in Irish Street, Downpatrick, three people sat talking, Mrs McLean, her husband, Thomas, and her mother, Mrs OrsquoKelly.As they sipped tea and partook of what treats the ration book allowed, they had an idea. The plan was to bring entertainment to the war weary inhabitants of the town.This meeting would lead to the formation of St Patrickrsquos Operatic and Pantomime Society and their first production was Phyllis, the Farmerrsquos Daughter mdash a title that has dated somewhat.The public responded by volunteering as actors, stage hands, working with costumes and music.Principals and chorus rehearsed separately. Only one week before opening night did they merge, coming together for the first time on the stage of St Patrickrsquos Hall.It was advertised as lsquoA Feast of Music, Song and Dancersquo boasting  voices. Rehearsal took place in the McLean home, the cast rehearsed upstairs, while machinists and costumiers worked downstairs.Phyllis, the Farmerrsquos Daughter was performed on Sunday, May , and Monday, May , .It proved successful enough to be followed in  by other productions such as Tangles, The Enchanted Rose and Quest of Olwen.The performances, in the absence of film footage and photographs, appear to be lost in the haze of time.Tangles, described as a grand musical comedy, was performed in St Patrickrsquos Hall on Monday, June , the night before the Normandy Landings. The performance was in aid of the Down County Infirmary.The programme included cast and production notes. The actors, credited as lsquoMortalsrsquo included Michael Tomelty as Lollipop, Sally King as Princess Pansy, Lillian Lundy as Dame Mouldy, Leslie Rice as Lord Humbug and Master Michael Rea as the Inn Keeperrsquos Son. lsquoImmortalsrsquo included Peggy Halloran as Titania, Maura Blaney as Nona and Mary Gilmore as lsquoCinderellarsquo.Also included was an array of guardsmen, a chorus of fairies, village chorus, court dancers, innkeeper chorus, fairy partners, bunnies and a chorus of gnomes, who included Maureen Dorrian, Annie Murphy and June Doyle. In all, the cast numbered .The scenic artist was Mr James Maguire and the costume designer was Mrs OrsquoKelly. In charge of actors make-up were Mrs Maguire, Kathleen Branf and Mrs Gilmore.But, what was the story  With appearances from gnomes and Cinderella it may have had a little to do with fairyland.Is there anyone out there who remembers  At this distance, it is just a forgotten show, one of many that enter-tained people at a most dficult time in history.Around Lecale and where, there were a number of amateur dramatic companies, many more than today, who performed many shows. Here are but a sample.Old King Cole by May King, with nine scenes and a chorus of , was a three-hour show, staged in St Patrickrsquos Hall, Downpatrick, at pm on Sunday, February , .Reserved tickets were on sale from Mr Breen, Mr Fox and Mr Doris.Ballykilbeg Dramatic Society gave the public a production of Paul Twyning by George Shiels on Sunday, March , and Tuesday, March , , with a repeat performance in St Patrickrsquos Hall, Downpatrick, the following Sunday.Kilclief Parish Amateur Dramatic Club staged Shielsrsquo new comedy, The Fort Field, in St Malachyrsquos Hall in the village on Sunday, May , . They also performed it in the Stella Maris Hall in Strangford the following Friday.Killyleagh Dramatic Society presented St John Ervinersquos lsquoBoydrsquos Shop at the Belfast Dramatic Festival during the first week of September , having staged it during the late summer of that year in Strangford.On the night of Sunday, November , , you could treat yourself to Stars over Ballynoe, an all-star iety concert in St Patrickrsquos Parochial Hall, Ballynoe, with Alister Dick, the famous Irish tenor, Alfie Donnelly, Irelandrsquos funniest comedian, the Legamaddy Dancers and the Portaferry Hawaiian Band. The compere was Joseph Caher.Woodgrange Platoon Home Guard presented The Lilac Ribbon by Downpatrick born playwright Lynn Doyle in the Woodgrange Orange Hall on Friday, January , .The Whip Hand was performed by the Stella Maris Players in the Parochial Hall, Saul, on Sunday, May , .The Bryansford Players staged The Rale True Doctor and Professor Tim in St Patrickrsquos Hall, Bryansford, on Sunday, April , , and in St Maryrsquos Hall, Newcastle, on Sunday and Monday, April  and .The Pikemen Orsquo the Ards, described as ldquothe grand Irish drama in five acts, was presented in Dunsford Hall on Sunday, April , , by the Cruachan Cowey Dramatic Club, with Irish selections by the Silver Star Band, Portaferry.With television, the internet and computer games there appears to be less interest today in local drama groups. Even so, it is a pleasant surprise how many children and young people wish to be involved in drama, comedy and musicals.Amateur drama companies still remain. The quality of the plays and shows from  years ago visited in this article can only be guessed athellip..or did you take part .prettyPhoto

title: Author’s bookshelf just got bigger with new book
story: PROLIFIC Downpatrick author Joe McCoubrey has added to his growing list of titles.The former journalist and business development consultant has just published book number  in a series of action thrillers that stretch back almost  years.ldquoI try to aim for about one a year, and so far itrsquos working out pretty well. Hopefully, therersquos more to come, he said.Joersquos latest work is QUINN - No Place to Hide, a standalone follow-up to a successful launch of the first in the series. The title is dedicated to his great grandfather, Sam Quinn, a man Joe admired for the way in which he dealt with the harshness of le in Downpatrick at the turn of the twentieth century.ldquoHe worked -hour shts, six days a week, as a yard foreman at the Rearsquos bottling plant in Market Street, Downpatrick. It was backbreaking work for which he earned a pittance to feed a large family. He never complained, never took a holiday, and never ventured outside the confines of the town. He lived through two world wars, the creation of the Irish Republic, and countless other momentous times, yet he kept his head down and simply got on with his own le.Joe is quick to point out that the character in his latest book is nothing like his ancestor. ldquoAll Irsquove taken is his name. My version of Quinn is that of an international assassin who leaves Downpatrick to join the Irish Rangers and later becomes a gun for hire in America. Talk about two dferent worlds! Perhaps though, therersquos a bit of parallel in that I transferred old Sam Quinnrsquos stoicism and relentless nature into a make-believe cut-out who lives his le by those very ideals.With a -year background in journalism, it was hardly surprising that Joe wanted to keep writing when he switched careers in  to head up Down Business Centre, a support enterprise agency to help promote start-up businesses.He said: ldquoI loved the interaction with local entrepreneurs, but the writing bug doesnrsquot go away. I had always an idea for a book and couldnrsquot stop scratching the itch. After a few years, I decided to put it into action.That first book mdash SOMEONE HAS TO PAY mdash was a product of the Northern Ireland Troubles. It is set in the unlikely surroundings of Bishopscourt, a former RAF base just outside Downpatrick, and features a British government elite squad assembled under the relative anonymity of the old complex for the purposes of waging a final shoot-to-kill war against the IRA.Joersquos own assessment of the story brings a wry smile. ldquoItrsquos a far-fetched idea, isnrsquot it  It couldnrsquot have happened, could it  Thatrsquos the essence of the storyteller and I guess itrsquos why I love doing it.A recurring theme in Joersquos books is that he likes toin a mention of his hometown whenever possible. Yoursquoll find Downpatrick cropping up a lot in background narratives, or as the setting for a few hair-raising episodes that attempt to weave their way into the history and fabric of the area.ldquoItrsquos just something I like to do. Irsquom a Downpatrick man and I have the urge to shout about it when the chance arises. Wersquove a lot going for us in this area and it can only do good to let the world know wersquore here.One of his other books SPENT FORCE, which was a crime thriller set in the West of Ireland and featured a fading Garda detective, attracted praise from two signicant sources. One was Ken Bruen, the international bestselling author of the Jack Taylor Irish crime series, who wrote: ldquoSometimes a book comes along that you instantly know......damn, I am now going to have to read this all over again for the sheer joy of the narrative. It means that I will have to swear off other books for a time as very few can provide the utter joy and delight of Joe McCoubreyrsquos superb novel.Another unexpected source was a serving Garda sergeant who posted a glowing review on the Amazon . ldquoA top-class novel which deserves high praise. I am from Irish law enforcement and this novel is as close to a real-le investigation as you can get. Gripping from start to finish, totally believable characters, strong storyline, Highly Recommended.Joe admits he was floored by the feedback. ldquoOn the one hand there was an endorsement by perhaps Irelandrsquos foremost crime thriller author, while on the other there was vindication from a policeman that the research and effort to get things right had paid off. Itrsquos what any author craves, and itrsquos what makes you want to get back over the keyboard and start into the next adventure.That next adventure is taking Joe back to the West of Ireland to team up again with his favourite Garda detective. The sequel is provisionally titled FORCE OF NATURE which delves into the murky world of a serial killer. Not surprisingly, Downpatrick features heavily again.ldquoYes, the killerrsquos first three victims are young girls from Downpatrick. The story will move from here to Westport and back again. Irsquom still not sure how it will end, and thatrsquos as much an appeal to me as it is to the reader.Joe explains that hersquos not a dedicated story plotter. ldquoI use a broad brush. I get an idea and just run with it. I donrsquot like to be confined to structure from start to finish, with the result that Irsquom not quite sure where Irsquom going from one chapter to another. I think of it as being spontaneous, which means I usually go off on tangents that keeps things fresh and moving along. Itrsquos a seat-of-the-pants alternative to being a plotter.Joe publishes all his books under his own publishing house, Inishfree Communications, which also offers support to local writers. To date, he has helped eight others to complete their author journey ndash between them they have published more than  titles. He provides proofing, formatting, and design services, including suggestions on the most effective covers for inidual books.ldquoItrsquos a big part of what I do these days, says Joe. ldquoThere are lots of budding writers and independent authors out there who just need a bit of extra help and encouragement to bring their work in front of the masses. I get as much of a kick out of seeing these books go on sale as I do from my own works.Joe McCoubreyrsquos books are available as paperbacks or eBooks on the Amazon and Barnes  Noble s..prettyPhoto

title: Call for hedge removal after near miss
story: AN overgrown hedge close to a BT exchange in Killyleagh is being blamed for a near miss involving a pedestrian and a bus last week.A woman who was forced to step on to the main road to avoid the hedge was almost struck by the vehicle as it passed, leaving both her and the driver shaken.BT has confirmed that it plans to cut the hedge this week, but local councillor Billy Walker said the telecoms giant must go further and remove it completely.He said there was a wall behind the hedge, suggesting that once the hedge is removed, BT would only have to build a small fence on top of it to secure its base.ldquoThe overgrown hedge has been an issue for many years and there have been countless near misses involving people who have had to step off the footpath to pass, including mums with prams. What happened last Friday is the final straw as far as I am concerned, declared Cllr Walker.ldquoThe only sensible solution is to remove the hedge in its entirety. To do so would not cost a lot of money, but would save lives as at this time of year as people would not have to walk on a busy main road to pass.Cllr Walker says he has raised the issue with the telecoms company over the years, but was told the hedge could not be cut back as it was the nesting season.ldquoMy biggest fear has always been that someone could end up getting killed or seriously injured at this part of Killyleagh. While I am thankful the woman who stepped off the footpath last Friday was not seriously injured, this must be the last incident of this kind, said Cllr Walker.ldquoI am appealing to BT to do the decent thing and finally remove the hedge. We have been fortunate up until now no one has been injured, but I shudder to think what could happen at this location.Cllr Walker added: ldquoThis situation is a major accident waiting to happen, but it can be avoided by simply removing a hedge. It is s no brainer and I hope BT will agree to my request.A BT spokesperson said the organisation was sorry to learn of the distress that the hedge may have caused and would be in contact with Cllr Walker directly.ldquoThe hedge is scheduled to be trimmed back this week. We are sorry for any inconvenience in the meantime, added the spokesperson..prettyPhoto

title: Centre hoping to benefit from holidaying at home
story: AN international visitor attraction in Downpatrick is set to open its doors following two months of closure due to the coronavirus pandemic.Dr Tim Campbell, director of the St Patrickrsquos Centre, says the facility is preparing for an expected summer boom of visitors.As the lockdown began staff at the centre were placed on furlough, but Dr Campbell is now planning a major new drive for business.ldquoThe hundreds of international groups which had already booked to visit Downpatrick may unfortunately not come this year and so we must completely change our business strategy, he said.ldquoWe will support our partners in the coach business toin future years of course, but for now we must take advantage of the lsquostaycationrsquo boom which is projected in the late summer and autumn and drive local, UK and Republic of Ireland business to Downpatrick.Dr Campbell said that he believed the new period of holidaying at home will give Downpatrick an opportunity to showcase its many attractions.He added: ldquoI think there is a real opportunity for experiences from our local community to emerge which we at the St Patrick Centre will promote.ldquoWe want to show our pride and passion for where we live ndash be that sharing your favourite walk or volunteer as a community guide.Dr Campbell said that prior to Covid-, the centre was in the process of implementing new measures to grow its business following a strategic review by Newry, Mourne and Down Council which saw the centre as being pivotal role in supporting other local tourist attractions.ldquoAs a result a new five star group of local attractions has been formed led by the Centre which includes Down County Museum, Down Cathedral, Downpatrick Railway Museum and Down Arts Centre. The centre is also coordinating the creation of a VisitDownpatrick website, he remarked.Dr Campbell said St Patrick provided a ldquounique selling point for our area and and an overall brand.He added: ldquoAs this is potentially a year of two winters, we have asked the council to revert to their  contributions to the centre to help us survive and be able to change direction.ldquoThis means giving the centre a little more, particularly because as a small charity in a big building we have not been able to get any of the funding from government made available to other groups and organisations.ldquoIf tourism, as the most important part of our economy in mid Down is to not just survive but thrive we need to be armed with not just a shield, but a sword to fight this battle..prettyPhoto

title: Climbing to top of Mount Everest
story: MOUNT Everest, , feet, or , metres, of awe-inspiring, dficult, adventurous, dangerous climbing. Some people have looked at Everest and thought climbing it is necessary. Others call those people crazy.Everesting is described as ldquofiendishly simple, yet brutally hard. Ride hill repeats on any hill anywhere in the world mdash or on Zwt, the virtual cycling simulator mdash in a single activity until you climb the equivalent height of Mount Everest.The concept was created by Hells , who also control the induction into the Everesting Hall of Fame. Website Everesting.cc contains the rules to follow.Well, call me crazy, but I did it. No, I didnrsquot fly to Nepal and climb the actual mountain. Irsquom not a former pro athlete or extraordinarily gted human, nor am I an adventure adrenaline junkie looking for a fix. Irsquom just a  something mdash  to be precise mdash son of God who has a family, a job, a dog, a bicycle, and I landed myself in the Everesting Hall of Fame. And you can too.I decided to use the challenge to help raise funds for mental health organisations Aware and Ballynahinch Counselling Service, or The Hub, as itrsquos known locally. My initial target was pound but I was astounded and humbled by the generosity of people. In the end donations totalled pound,.I chose to start at am so I could have family support at the finish. Despite the early start I was joined by my we, Jennie, and through the day she was a great support, bringing me fresh drinks and relaying messages of support.I turned on my favourite music playlist and hit the hill with a measured effort that I thought I could sustain for hours. I planned a bidon of sports drink for each ascent, as well as -g carbs per hour. Real foods early in the ride and gels and sugary drinks for later in the ride.The first three or four ascents felt strangely comfortable, averaging  minutes up each time. I was almost an hour ahead of my estimated -hour schedule by midday. I later noticed some friends,, who were tracking my progress, were saying how strong I was riding and hoped that I wouldnrsquot pay for it later.They were right! Ascents six and seven were so tough, even to the point where I felt physically ill, and my times were now over  minutes per climb.vEveresters add the tag lsquovEverestingrsquo to their Zwt profile name which means anyone on the course that sees it knows you are vEveresting and many will ride with you, congratulate you, give you a thumbs up, or just encourage you to keep going.These wonderful sherpas made it a much more enjoyable experience, especially during the sixth and seventh ascents when it was dficult to want to keep riding and my butt was telling me that I was crazy to push on.Despite wanting to reach the finish as soon as possible, I had to listen to my body, and so I stopped for some food and a bit of a rest. Another quick shower, kit change and application of chamois cream, and I was ready to continue.I was joined online this time by good friends Nathan Mullan and Stephen Hanna, both from Dromara Cycling Club, and Sam Carmichael and Nigel Bradley, from my old club, Northwest CC. Seeing them there gave me a real boost and that combined with knowing I had the end in sight really spurred me on to the finish.The final  metres of climbing were the best - I was getting messages of encouragement from Zwters from places as far away as Germany, USA and Colombia. I finished shortly after pm, over  hours after I first leapt into the saddle and boy did I sleep well that night.So to finish, Irsquod like to say a huge thanks to everyone for their support, to those who donated in such hard times mdash Irsquom so grateful and Irsquom hopeful we will make le that little bit easier for others.I havenrsquot put any thought into the next challenge mdash on Sunday I said never again mdash but the beauty of cycling is therersquos always the next time. For now Irsquoll enjoy the beautul scenery of Co Down. See you on the road..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar family giving children loving foster home
story: IT takes a special kind of person to be a foster carer, but for Crossgar foster mum Tanya Dickson, the only regret she has is that she and her husband Colin didnrsquot do it sooner.They are preparing to say goodbye to three year-old Mary*, a child they have cared for the last two years, as she leaves them to be adopted by a couple.Tanya and Colin ndash who call themselves and their  year-old daughter, Hannah, Team Dickson as they are all devoted to fostering ndash are bracing themselves for when the time comes, while knowing that itrsquos in the best interests of the little girl.Tanya said: ldquoEvery child that is with us is part of our family. Thatrsquos something our whole extended family embraces.ldquoItrsquos going to be bittersweet but we are happy for Mary and the lovely couple who are adopting her. Itrsquos good to know that she will be going to her forever home and will have a lovely little le. Thatrsquos always the ultimate aim for a child, particularly a younger child.ldquoHowever, one of the challenges is trying to teach her about adoption. How do you teach a three year-old that she will be leaving us and going to a forever family  We had to be creative and came up with the idea about the Christmas elf. Like many houses, we had Bauble the elf at Christmas, who was then lsquoadoptedrsquo by Mary and now lives with us all year round and is part of our family. We even made an adoption certicate to show her it was real.ldquoWhile Covid- has put a hold on this for now, we still have to prepare both Mary and ourselves, as it will be hard to say goodbye. But, as our daughter keeps saying, itrsquos part of foster care and what is right for Mary.ldquoEveryone has been writing their goodbye letters to her. We have prepared a book about her time with us and videos so that she wonrsquot have any gaps when shersquos looking back on her le.The Dicksons have been fostering since  and have looked after eight children so far, ranging in age from one to eight. They do respite fostering ndash temporary childcare for another fosterer or family ndash and short-term foster care.Itrsquos something that the couple have wanted to do for a long time.ldquoI wanted to foster for as long as in my early twenties and my husband felt the same, said  year-old Tanya. ldquoWe both came from family backgrounds where close relatives were in the caring professions.ldquoWe were very united in knowing that we would foster one day, even from the day we were married. However, when our daughter Hannah came along, we wanted her to be part of it, obviously, and to wait until the time that we were sure she understood the impact of it.ldquoWe waited until she was about  before we contacted the South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust. Thatrsquos where our journey started, and we havenrsquot looked back once. The Trust has been with us every step of the way. The only regret we have had about fostering is not doing it sooner.The Dicksons have also been supported by their nearest and dearest in doing something that many other people consider doing.ldquoWe were lucky that our families were always on board with us regarding our fostering, Tanya said. Our employers have been amazing, our church family and even the village family of Crossgar. Everyone has really embraced our fostering journey.After making contact with the Trust Tanya, who works at Kilmood Early Years Playgroup, said that after a period of assessment and training they began to foster six months later.ldquoI think the assessment can put people off, but I believe itrsquos an invaluable tool as you come out of it knowing yourself better, she explained. You know your own personal qualities better and your skill base.ldquoItrsquos also essential as it helps the Trust match children with dferent needs with dferent foster carers. The only thing we stipulated is that any child we cared for would be at least two years younger than Hannah as we wanted her to be the eldest child in the house.Hannah, who is a student of Saintfield High School, has been integral to the couplersquos success as foster parents and has relished her role as lsquobig sisterrsquo.Mrs Dickson said: ldquoHannah has been so great with the children. With Hannah maturing, she is showing her experience of fostering in a very positive and beautul way by showing empathy to others.ldquoThatrsquos something she would never have experienced had we not fostered and she feels more grateful for her family le. She wants to be a nurse and I can see that great caring spirit being fostered in her care of Mary. Itrsquos been so rewarding and has changed us completely for the better.Unlike many first-time parents, Tanya said foster parents always have help and support available.She said: ldquoEvery child that comes through our door is dferent and you adapt accordingly for whatever that child needs. We have the support of a link worker, who has had a lot of training. Yoursquore never on your own.ldquoWe have learnt to take things at a childrsquos pace. Some children who have been looked after before are used to being more independent and self-sufficient.
